questions.text: A 57-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician 2 weeks after noticing a lump in her right breast. Her last mammogram was performed 4 years ago and showed no abnormalities. Menopause began 2 years ago, during which time the patient was prescribed hormone replacement therapy for severe hot flashes and vaginal dryness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right breast shows a firm, nontender mass close to the nipple. There are no changes in the skin or nipple, and there is no palpable axillary adenopathy. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Mammography shows a suspicious 2-cm mass adjacent to the nipple. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fine needle aspiration (FNA) cytology cannot provide information about the tissue architecture or receptor status. In patients with a palpable breast lump and suspicious findings on imaging, FNA has been superseded by a more sensitive and more specific modality. The primary role of FNA nowadays is the evaluation of nonsuspicious, cystic lesions in women younger than 30 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Excisional biopsy (e.g., via lumpectomy) is an invasive procedure and is therefore not the most appropriate next step in diagnosing breast cancer. It may, however, be used for diagnosis in this patient if the appropriate next step is inconclusive but imaging shows a suspicious lesion or if the appropriate next step cannot be performed (e.g., lack of facilities or expertise for ultrasound-guided procedures).

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with suspected breast cancer, a bone scan is indicated in patients with localized bone pain and/or increased ALP and in all patients with stage III breast cancer or higher. In this patient, whose lymph nodes do not show signs of disease and who does not have bone pain, it would be inappropriate to perform a bone scan before performing tissue diagnosis and axillary staging.

D) INCORRECT:

CA15-3, which is a tumor marker in patients with breast cancer, is used for the follow-up of patients who have already received treatment and not for the diagnosis of breast cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

A mastectomy would be indicated if histological examination of the tissue specimen obtained by the appropriate next step suggested breast cancer, and breast-conserving therapy was not indicated (e.g., tumor > 5 cm, a mass with microcalcifications, or a widespread disease that cannot be removed via single incision), or if the patient wished to undergo mastectomy. In a patient with a palpable breast lump, a mastectomy should not be performed without confirmation of breast cancer by tissue diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

A core needle biopsy is the most appropriate next step in the management of a patient with a palpable breast lump and imaging findings suggestive of breast cancer. This test is used to confirm the diagnosis, evaluate the extent of the tumor, and describe the histology of the tumor and its receptor profile.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis
questions.hint: This patient has suspicious findings on mammography and multiple risk factors for breast cancer, including nulliparity, late menopause, and hormone replacement therapy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old primigravid woman at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a follow-up examination for a mass she found in her left breast 2 weeks ago. Menarche occurred at the age of 11 years, and menses occurred at 30- to 40-day intervals until pregnancy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 3-cm, firm, nontender, nonmobile mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 20-week gestation. Ultrasound and ultrasound-guided core biopsy confirm an infiltrating lobular carcinoma. The pathological specimen is positive for estrogen and ERBB2 receptors and negative for progesterone receptors. Staging shows no distant metastatic disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection is associated with minimal risk to the fetus regardless of gestational age, but radiotherapy is contraindicated during pregnancy because of the risk of fetal damage.

B) CORRECT:

Surgical resection (i.e., breast-conserving surgery or mastectomy with or without axillary node dissection) poses little risk to the fetus at any gestational age. Because her tumor is 3 cm, this patient is considered high risk and should therefore undergo adjuvant chemotherapy. Certain chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, fluorouracil) have a low risk profile and can be used in the second or third trimester of pregnancy. Chemotherapy should be discontinued 3–4 weeks before delivery to reduce the risk of complications (e.g., transient neonatal myelosuppression, bleeding, sepsis) during childbirth and in the postpartum period.

A 3–6 month delay in chemotherapy is associated with less favorable outcomes in nonpregnant individuals. Therefore, physicians should counsel patients through open communication and shared decision-making, according to their individual treatment needs. Patients have the right to refuse chemotherapy and/or delay treatment until after delivery.

C) INCORRECT:

Trastuzumab can be considered in nonpregnant patients who have an ERBB2-positive tumor. However, because of the fetal complications associated with trastuzumab (e.g., pulmonary hypoplasia, fetal death), this medication should not be used in pregnant individuals.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of hormonal therapy and trastuzumab is a recommended adjuvant treatment after surgical resection for estrogen-receptor-positive, ERBB2-positive breast cancer. However, both treatment options are contraindicated during pregnancy because of the risk of fetal damage.

E) INCORRECT:

Termination of pregnancy is not recommended in this patient because there is treatment available that is associated with only minimal risk of fetal damage. Furthermore, pregnancy termination is not associated with better breast cancer survival.
questions.hint: Early-stage infiltrating lobular carcinoma is usually treated with breast-conserving surgery and adjuvant systemic therapy. For gestational breast cancer, it is important to offer a treatment regimen with a low risk of fetal damage.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician for the evaluation of a palpable mass in her right breast that she first noticed 1 week ago. She has no associated pain. She has never had a mammogram. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. She has no family history of breast cancer. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a firm, nonpainful, nonmobile mass in the right upper quadrant of the breast. There is no nipple discharge. Examination of the skin and lymph nodes shows no abnormalities. No masses are palpated in the left breast. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI scan of the breast is indicated for the workup of a suspicious breast lump when routine imaging tests are inconclusive or as a screening tool when the patient has an increased risk for breast cancer (e.g., a BRCA mutation carrier). However, none of these conditions apply.

B) CORRECT:

Mammography is the recommended imaging modality for the evaluation of a palpable breast mass in women ≥ 30 years of age. Along with clinical assessment, it is the initial step in breast cancer diagnosis and helps in deciding whether a biopsy is further required.

Ultrasonography is the initial imaging modality of choice in women < 30 years of age.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis

C) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration is the recommended diagnostic modality for evaluating a nonsuspicious breast mass (e.g., soft movable mass), but is performed after imaging. This patient also already has signs concerning for malignancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Although core needle biopsy is part of the workup of breast lumps when there is suspicion of malignancy, it is performed after imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

BRCA gene testing is recommended for evaluating breast cancer in patients with a family history of breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer, or in some patients after breast cancer is diagnosed (e.g., triple-negative or bilateral breast cancer). However, none of these conditions apply.

F) INCORRECT:

A monthly self-breast exam is not a recommended strategy for this patient since she has a breast lump concerning for breast cancer, which requires further workup.

G) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography is the recommended initial imaging test for a self-palpated breast lump in women younger than 30 years of age because it offers higher sensitivity than a mammogram. Young women have higher density breast tissue, which makes the detection of breast abnormalities in a mammogram more difficult.
questions.hint: This patient's nontender, firm, nonmobile breast mass should raise concern for breast cancer.

questions.text:
The patient undergoes mammography, which shows a 6.5-mm mass with an irregular border and spiculated margins. A subsequent core needle biopsy of the mass shows infiltrating ductal carcinoma with ERBB2-positive, estrogen-negative, and progesterone-negative immunohistochemistry staining. Blood counts and liver function tests are normal. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL


Serum



Na+

140 mEq/L


Cl-

103 mEq/L


K+

4.2 mEq/L


HCO3-

26 mEq/L


Ca2+

8.9 mg/dL


Urea nitrogen
12 mg/dL


Glucose
95 mg/dL


Alkaline phosphatase
30 U/L


Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
15 U/L


Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
13 U/L


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Breast-conserving surgery and sentinel lymph node biopsy
Fine-needle aspiration of the lymph nodes
Bilateral mastectomy with lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Breast-conserving surgery (BCS) and sentinel node biopsy are diagnostic and therapeutic procedures used as a first-line intervention in patients with newly-diagnosed invasive ductal carcinoma. All patients who undergo BCS (e.g., lumpectomy) require postoperative radiation to the whole breast to minimize the risk of recurrence. Sentinel node biopsy is necessary for cancer staging, which will determine subsequent treatment. Moreover, given the ERBB2-positive immunohistochemical staining, this patient will benefit from ERBB2-targeted therapy in the form of trastuzumab.

B) INCORRECT:

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that is primarily used in patients with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer, but this patient's stain is estrogen receptor-negative.

C) INCORRECT:

Axillary staging is indicated for all patients with breast cancer. Although this patient's axillary node status should be evaluated, imaging-guided fine-needle aspiration is typically only indicated in patients with palpable lymph nodes. Another step in management is more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

A whole-body PET/CT scan is required in all patients with stage IIIA or higher disease to assess for metastases. Additionally, patients who present with signs of metastatic disease, such as abdominal pain, elevated liver function tests, or palpable abdominal masses, may benefit from a whole-body PET/CT scan. However, the stage of this patient's cancer has not yet been determined and she does not have any signs of metastatic disease, so a whole-body PET/CT would not be indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

A bilateral mastectomy with lymph node dissection is commonly performed in patients with bilateral disease, or in patients who have a BRCA gene mutation. Although a BRCA mutation has not explicitly been ruled out in this patient, BRCA mutation carriers generally have a personal and/or family history of breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer, and may also have more advanced disease at presentation (triple-negative or bilateral breast cancer). This patient does not have any of these conditions, which makes a BRCA mutation unlikely. In addition, an ERBB2 mutation has already been identified as the likely culprit.

F) INCORRECT:

A bone scan is commonly obtained in patients who present with bone pain or elevated alkaline phosphatase in the setting of newly diagnosed breast cancer, which may be indicative of metastatic disease. This patient does not have either of these findings.
questions.hint: Given the results of mammography and core-needle biopsy, this patient most likely has localized breast cancer. She will require further staging and treatment.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician for a mass in her left breast she noticed 2 days ago during breast self-examination. She has hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine. There is no family history of breast cancer. Examination shows large, moderately ptotic breasts. The mass in her left breast is small (approximately 1 cm x 0.5 cm), firm, mobile, and painless. It is located 4 cm from her nipple-areolar complex at the 7 o'clock position. There are no changes in the skin or nipple, and there is no palpable axillary adenopathy. No masses are palpable in her right breast. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Mammogram shows a soft tissue mass with poorly defined margins. Core needle biopsy confirms a low-grade infiltrating ductal carcinoma. The pathological specimen is positive for estrogen receptors and negative for progesterone and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (ERBB2) receptors. Staging shows no distant metastatic disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Nipple-sparing mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection followed by hormone therapy
Nipple-sparing mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection, followed by radiation and hormone therapy
Lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy followed by hormone therapy
Radical mastectomy followed by hormone therapy
Lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy, followed by radiation and hormone therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Less extensive surgical excision provides the same survival outcomes for early breast cancer as nipple-sparing mastectomy. In addition, axillary lymph node dissection can cause complications such as lymphedema and would only be indicated if the patient had a previous lymph node biopsy that was positive.

B) INCORRECT:

Although a selected group of patients may request aggressive management of early breast cancer with a nipple-sparing mastectomy, less extensive surgical procedures have proven to provide the same survival outcomes with fewer complications. In early-stage breast cancer, mastectomy may be performed because of patient preference or a large tumor-to-breast ratio, neither of which is the case for this patient. Moreover, axillary lymph node dissection may cause complications such as lymphedema and would only be indicated if the patient had a previous lymph node biopsy that was positive.

C) INCORRECT:

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is indicated for all patients with no clinical signs of axillary lymph node involvement in order to rule out microscopic spread and determine the cancer stage, which will determine the subsequent course of treatment. Given that this patient has a hormone receptor-positive cancer, she would also benefit from adjuvant hormone therapy. However, all patients who undergo lumpectomy require one additional therapeutic modality in order to minimize the risk of recurrence.

D) INCORRECT:

Radical mastectomy is very rarely used in the modern treatment of early-stage invasive breast cancer because it is associated with high rates of complications (e.g., lymphedema, sensory deficits under the axilla) and does not provide additional survival benefit when compared with less invasive options.

E) CORRECT:

Treatment of early-stage invasive breast cancer involves breast-conserving surgery (BCS), sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB), as well as adjuvant radiation therapy. SLNB is necessary for cancer staging, which will determine subsequent treatment. All patients who undergo BCS (e.g., lumpectomy) require adjuvant radiation therapy to minimize the risk of recurrence. Given that this patient has hormone receptor-positive cancer, she should also receive adjuvant endocrine therapy (e.g., tamoxifen).
questions.hint: This patient has early-stage, invasive breast cancer with a small tumor-to-breast ratio and no clinically apparent skin, nipple, or axillary lymph node involvement.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because she palpated a mass in her right breast during self-examination a week ago. Menarche was at the age of 14, and her last menstrual period was at the age of 51. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a nontender, firm, hard mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. Mammography shows large, dense breasts, with a 1.7-cm mass in the right upper outer quadrant. The patient undergoes right upper outer quadrant lumpectomy with subsequent sentinel node biopsy, which reveals moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma and micrometastasis to one axillary lymph node. There is no evidence of extranodal metastasis. The tumor tests positive for both estrogen and progesterone receptors and does not show human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (ERBB2) over-expression. Flow-cytometry reveals aneuploid tumor cells. Which of the following factors has the greatest effect on this patient's prognosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Women < 40 years old are thought to have an increased risk of aggressive, high-grade cancers, while in women > 65 years old, overall morbidity and frailty are the main contributing factors to poor outcome. However, age is not the most important prognostic factor.

B) INCORRECT:

A DNA ploidy status showing an increased number of cells containing abnormal chromosome counts (aneuploidy) is thought to be a sign of rapidly dividing tumor cells and is associated with a poorer prognosis. However, it is a nonspecific finding and is not considered the most important prognostic factor.

C) INCORRECT:

Since the findings of mammography do not confirm the diagnosis of breast cancer and provide no information on the histologic grade and possible metastases, they are not considered a prognostic factor.

D) INCORRECT:

Large (> 5 cm) breast tumors are associated with a poorer prognosis. However, another factor has a greater effect on prognosis than tumor size.

E) CORRECT:

The status of axillary lymph nodes in patients with breast cancer is considered one of the most important prognostic factors for disease outcome. If axillary lymph nodes are involved, metastatic spread to other organs is likely and survival rates are lower. Detection of metastases in the lymph nodes is also associated with higher recurrence rates of cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

The findings of moderately differentiated tumor cells in this patient are consistent with an intermediate histologic tumor grade. While higher histologic grades negatively affect the prognosis in breast cancer patients, another prognostic factor is more important.

G) INCORRECT:

A positive ERBB2 receptor status in breast cancer patients is associated with aggressive tumor growth, high-grade tumors, and a poor prognosis, especially if the estrogen and progesterone hormone receptor status are negative. Since this patient's ERBB2 receptor status is negative, it does not have a negative impact on her prognosis. Regardless, another factor is even more important.

H) INCORRECT:

While a positive receptor status is a risk factor for increased cancer growth, a negative receptor status is associated with a poorer prognosis, since it means targeted hormone therapy cannot be given. However, the hormone receptor status is not the most important prognostic factor.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of an itchy rash on her left nipple. The rash began as small vesicles on the nipple and spread to the areola. It has become a painful ulcer with yellow, watery discharge that is occasionally blood-tinged. She has asthma treated with theophylline and inhaled salbutamol. Her younger sister was diagnosed with endometrial cancer a year ago. Examination shows a weeping, ulcerated lesion involving the entire left nipple-areolar complex. There are no breast masses, dimpling, or axillary lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) would have a rapidly progressive clinical course, and involvement of the nipple-areola complex in IBC can result in itching and ulceration of the nipple as well as bloody nipple discharge. However, more than a third of the breast will be erythematous, tender, indurated, and edematous with a “peau d'orange” appearance. Palpable axillary lymph nodes are present at the time of clinical presentation in > 75% of cases.

B) INCORRECT:

Mastitis may be accompanied by fissuring of the nipple, and periductal mastitis can result in serous, serosanguinous, or purulent discharge. However, mastitis occurs typically among patients who are breastfeeding with an erythematous, tender, and swollen breast, and systemic symptoms such as fever would be present. Blood-tinged nipple discharge is usually not seen.

C) INCORRECT:

A breast abscess typically presents as a tender, palpable, fluctuant lump within the breast with erythema of the overlying skin, and systemic symptoms such as fever.

D) INCORRECT:

A fibroadenoma would present as a solid, nontender, breast lump that slips under the examiner's fingers. Nipple changes and discharge would not be present. Moreover, a fibroadenoma typically occurs in patients between the age of 15–35 years.

E) CORRECT:

Paget disease of the breast is a ductal carcinoma that infiltrates the nipple-areola complex causing an erythematous, scaly, or vesicular rash that is accompanied by pruritus, burning, and/or nipple retraction. The rash eventually ulcerates and causes blood-tinged nipple discharge.
Image Description:

An erythematous, scaling rash with irregular borders and erosion of the nipple is visible on the left breast of a female patient. The pathology extends beyond the areola region.

These findings are typical of Paget's disease of the breast, a rare type of ductal carcinoma that is often accompanied by nipple discharge. Age-appropriate imaging and biopsy are required for diagnosis.
questions.hint: Cytology of this lesion would show intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells within the epidermis of the nipple.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. One month ago, she was diagnosed with carcinoma of the left breast. She underwent a lumpectomy for a 2.1-cm mass and sentinel lymph node biopsy 2 weeks ago. The biopsy of the breast mass showed margin-free invasive ductal carcinoma; immunohistochemistry showed that carcinoma is estrogen-receptor and progesterone-receptor negative, and ERBB2-receptor positive. The lymph node biopsy was negative for metastases. Examination shows a healing surgical incision over the left breast. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Her physician decides to initiate treatment with appropriate pharmacotherapy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

ERBB2-positive tumors respond well to targeted therapy with trastuzumab and chemotherapeutic agents such as anthracyclines and taxanes. Before initiating treatment, an echocardiogram should be performed to evaluate cardiac function, since trastuzumab, anthracyclines, and taxanes are cardiotoxic (e.g., cause dilated cardiomyopathy with systolic congestive heart failure). The cardiotoxic effects may be limited with dexrazoxane, an iron-chelating agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Fundoscopy is indicated in patients treated with tamoxifen, which is the first-line treatment in premenopausal women with hormone-receptor-positive breast cancer. Tamoxifen may cause eye dryness, irritation, cataracts, and retinopathy (e.g., deposits in the retina and macula resulting in edema). This patient is hormone-receptor-negative and requires trastuzumab in addition to systemic chemotherapy, both of which have no major adverse effects on the eyes.

C) INCORRECT:

A DEXA scan is indicated for suspected osteoporosis, a complication of long-term therapy with aromatase inhibitors (e.g., anastrozole), which are the first-line treatment in postmenopausal women with hormone-receptor-positive breast cancer. This patient has an ERBB2-positive tumor that responds well to targeted therapy with trastuzumab and chemotherapeutic agents such as anthracyclines, both of which are not associated with a higher risk of osteoporosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Because trastuzumab and anthracyclines are cardiotoxic (e.g., cause dilated cardiomyopathy with systolic congestive heart failure), a detailed evaluation of cardiac function is necessary before initiating therapy. Although chest x-ray may reveal the first signs of cardiomyopathy (e.g., cardiomegaly, lung congestion), it is not the most appropriate next step.

E) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is performed in women who present with abnormal uterine bleeding while on tamoxifen therapy to screen for endometrial cancer. Tamoxifen is the first-line treatment in premenopausal women with estrogen and progesterone-receptor-positive breast cancer, but it may increase the risk of endometrial cancer and uterine sarcoma. However, according to immunohistochemistry, this patient has hormone-receptor-negative cancer cells.
questions.hint: ERBB2-positive  breast carcinomas require treatment with trastuzumab in addition to systemic chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no history of serious illness. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 11 years and last for 5 days. The first day of her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband and takes oral contraceptive pills. Her last Pap smear was 3 years ago. She has never had a mammogram. Her mother and maternal aunt died of breast cancer in their early 50s. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: Pap smear now and every 3 years, mammography at age 50 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every year, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear now and every 5 years, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 3 years, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 5 years, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 3 years, mammography at age 50 years

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

According to the USPSTF, a Pap smear every 3 years in individuals with a cervix who are 21–29 years of age is an acceptable screening method for cervical cancer. However, an additional test is required as a part of cervical cancer screening starting at the age of 30 years. In addition, breast cancer screening is typically started at 40 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years from 40–74 years of age. Also, this patient should now receive HPV testing along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should not be repeated annually because more frequent testing does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies.

C) INCORRECT:

Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years from 40–74 years of age. Also, the USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening every 5 years starting at 30 years of age. However, when screening every 5 years, the protocol requires another test in addition to the Pap smear. If the additional test cannot be performed, a Pap smear should be taken every 3 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years between 40–74 years of age. Also, the USPSTF recommends an HPV test along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer, starting at 30 years of age. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should be repeated every 5 years rather than every 3 years because more frequent screening does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies.

E) CORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years for individuals with a cervix who are 30–65 years of age and a solitary Pap smear every 3 years for those between 21–29 years of age. This guidance differs from the recently updated ASCCP, ACS, and ACOG guidelines, which recommend that those aged 25–65 years undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing (where available) or HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years. All guidelines recommend a solitary Pap smear every 3 years if HPV testing is unavailable.

Regarding breast cancer, mammography is rarely useful in younger patients, who have naturally denser breast tissue. According to the USPSTF, breast cancer screening with mammography should be performed every 2 years between 40–74 years of age. Screening can be started earlier in patients with first-degree relatives with breast cancer. Breast cancer screening recommendations may differ between medical organizations (e.g., ACOG, ACS). Consult our table “Breast cancer screening for individuals at average risk” for the most up-to-date information on breast cancer screening recommendations.

Whenever the information required to determine the correct answer for an NBME question involves a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF recommendations.

F) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends an HPV test along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer, starting at 30 years of age. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should be repeated every 5 years rather than every 3 years because more frequent screening does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies. Moreover, breast cancer screening is typically started at 40 years of age.
questions.hint: This patient is healthy and requires the standard screening tests for her age group and risk stratification according to USPSTF guidelines.

questions.text: A 93-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of a purple area on her right arm that has been growing for one month. She has not had any pain or itching of the area. She has hyperlipidemia, a history of basal cell carcinoma treated with Mohs surgery 2 years ago, and a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast treated with radical mastectomy 57 years ago. She has had chronic lymphedema of the right upper extremity since the mastectomy. Her only medication is simvastatin. She lives in an assisted living facility. She is content with her living arrangement but feels guilty that she is dependent on others. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows extensive edema of the right arm. Skin examination of the proximal upper right extremity shows three coalescing, 0.5–1.0 cm heterogeneous, purple plaques with associated ulceration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare, secondary malignancy that develops from endothelial cells as a result of chronic lymphedema (classically in individuals who have undergone axillary lymphadenectomy after mastectomy). Lymphangiosarcoma typically manifests with multiple purple macules and/or papules with possible ulceration, and less commonly with tender, subcutaneous nodules.
Image Description:

Photographic image of a woman with erythematous confluent macules and some papules in her right axillar region.

These lesions are typical for lymphangiosarcoma (e.g. after lymphadenectomy).

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic lymphedema is an important risk factor for the development of cellulitis and other soft tissue infections (including abscesses), and this patient is certainly at ongoing risk of infection given her long-standing edema. However, she does not have typical features of cellulitis (e.g., pain, erythema, warmth, tenderness, systemic symptoms), which makes an infection very unlikely.
Image Description:

Diffuse, poorly demarcated erythema and edema associated with small, crusted red patches are visible over the left leg.

These findings are consistent with cellulitis due to scabies infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Melanoma, a malignant skin cancer originating from melanocytes, should always be considered in the differential for a growing, asymmetric, hyperpigmented skin lesion. While this patient is at increased risk (age, previous skin cancer) for developing melanoma, the presence of chronic lymphedema is more consistent with a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Composite image showing 6 patients with superficial spreading melanoma

Of the ABCDE criteria of skin lesions concerning for melanoma, the lesion in image 1 fulfills only criteria A (asymmetry) and B (border irregularity). The lesions in images 2–6 fulfill criteria A, B, and C (color variegation). The lesion in image 2 also fulfills criterion D (diameter > 6 mm), which cannot be assessed in the other images in the absence of a measurement device. Criterion E (evolution: changes over time) cannot be assessed on single images.

D) INCORRECT:

Thrombophlebitis of a superficial vein typically manifests with erythema and tenderness along the vein and can cause congestion of venous vasculature distal to the thrombus. While upper extremity thrombophlebitis can have a similar distribution of lesions to that seen in this patient, it typically manifests with associated pain and erythema, which are not seen here. In addition, this patient's history of chronic lymphedema suggests a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Elder abuse should always be considered in an elderly patient presenting with possible bruises or hematomas. However, the chronicity, progressive growth in size, and history of lymphedema make an alternative diagnosis more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous lichen planus typically manifests with purple, polygonal, pruritic papules, or plaques (5 Ps) on the lower back, wrist, and/or ankles. It can also manifest with a lattice-like network of white stripes, called Wickham striae. This patient has no major features of lichen planus (pruritus, polygonal shape) and the distribution of her lesions in combination with chronic lymphedema suggests a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left wrist

Multiple erythematous papules, which are partially confluent are visible on the flexor side of the wrist. The papules are polygonal in shape and appear to be slightly elevated.

This finding is characteristic of cutaneous lichen planus. as polygonal, pink, slightly elevated, sharply demarcated, and partially confluent and partially grouped.

G) INCORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma may also manifest with purple skin plaques of the extremities that can progress to deeper, more nodular, and, occasionally, ulcerative, lesions. However, the lesions usually develop in severely immunocompromised patients (e.g., individuals with AIDS, transplant recipients). The absence of severe immunocompromise in this elderly woman makes this diagnosis highly unlikely. In addition, her history of chronic lymphedema suggests a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).
questions.hint: This condition occurs as a result of chronic lymphedema and is now considered rare since breast-sparing surgery techniques are favored and radical mastectomy has become less common.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician because of a 10-day history of small quantities of intermittent, blood-tinged discharge from her left nipple. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. Her last menstrual period was 12 days ago. She is sexually active and uses condoms inconsistently. Physical examination shows scant serosanguinous fluid expressible from the left nipple. There is no palpable breast mass or axillary lymphadenopathy. Examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) in premenopausal women can cause galactorrhea (bilateral nonbloody discharge). Common causes of physiological hyperprolactinemia include pregnancy and emotional stress, while those of pathological hyperprolactinemia include pituitary adenoma (manifests with headaches and bitemporal hemianopsia) or intake of certain drugs (e.g., antipsychotics, SSRIs). This patient has no history to suggest either physiological or pathological hyperprolactinemia and presents with unilateral sanguineous nipple discharge, which warrants a different workup.

B) INCORRECT:

Ductography is indicated in patients who present with pathological nipple discharge if other imaging is inconclusive or shows features suspicious of malignancy (e.g., ductal irregularity). Ductography is not routinely indicated for the evaluation of pathological nipple discharge because it is expensive, exposes the patient to radiation, and is technically difficult to perform. Also, most causes of nipple discharge in women < 30 years of age are benign.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with red flags for nipple discharge should be evaluated with imaging studies for lactiferous duct pathologies. Patients > 30 years of age should undergo ultrasonography AND diagnostic mammography to detect signs of ductal abnormalities (e.g., dilated ducts, ductal mass/nodule). For patients < 30 years of age, subareolar breast ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality; because breast tissue density is higher in this age group, a mammogram is less effective at detecting small lesions. Also, there is no ionizing radiation exposure associated with ultrasound imaging, unlike during a mammogram. If imaging reveals signs of malignancy, a biopsy of the lesion is indicated. Nonmilky nipple discharge is most commonly caused by benign conditions, such as intraductal papilloma or ductal ectasia, but may also be a sign of underlying malignancy (e.g., ductal carcinoma in situ).

In nonpregnant patients with bilateral, milky (nonbloody) nipple discharge (galactorrhea), laboratory assessment with measurement of serum prolactin levels is the first diagnostic step to evaluate for hyperprolactinemia.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis
TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

D) INCORRECT:

An image-guided biopsy can be performed in the diagnostic workup of patients with unilateral, nonmilky nipple discharge. However, this diagnostic step is reserved for those with evidence of malignancy (e.g., irregularity of a duct wall) on prior imaging studies.

E) INCORRECT:

Cytological examination of nipple discharge is not recommended because of its low sensitivity in detecting malignancy, high false-negative rates (a negative cytology does not definitively rule out malignancy), and low-cost effectiveness. In addition, cytology, if positive, does not help localize the lesion nor differentiate between an in situ and invasive carcinoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Mammography is recommended for the evaluation of focal breast findings (e.g., unilateral nipple discharge) in women > 30 years of age. However, this imaging modality is not recommended as the first-line diagnostic test in patients < 30 years of age. Breast tissue is very dense in this group, limiting the efficacy of mammograms to detect small lesions. Furthermore, mammography exposes the patient to ionizing radiation. Finally, the incidence of breast cancer in women < 30 years of age is low. Another diagnostic test for the evaluation of nipple discharge is, therefore, more appropriate in this patient group.

G) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is indicated in patients with nipple discharge that is consistent with normoprolactinemic galactorrhea. This condition manifests with bilateral milky discharge and normal prolactin levels. This patient, however, presents with unilateral, nonmilky nipple discharge, which requires further investigation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with red flags for nipple discharge (unilateral, spontaneous, and serosanguineous nipple discharge).

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician with concerns about swelling and pain in her right breast. Physical examination shows erythema and prominent pitting of the hair follicles overlying the upper and lower outer quadrants of the right breast. There are no nipple changes or discharge. A core needle biopsy shows invasive carcinoma of the breast. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's skin findings?

choices.text: Bacterial invasion of the subcutaneous tissue
Involution of the breast parenchyma and ductal system

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacterial invasion of the subcutaneous tissue of the breast causes mastitis, which can manifest as pain, erythema, and edema of the breast. Although peau d'orange appearance may occasionally be seen, most patients with mastitis will have fever, be actively lactating, or have a recent history of penetrating trauma that incited the infection. This patient has histopathological evidence that the signs are secondary to an invasive carcinoma of the breast.

B) CORRECT:

Obstruction of the dermal lymphatics by malignant tumor cells in inflammatory breast cancer results in localized lymphedema, which manifests as an increase in the size of the breast and the characteristic swollen and pitted appearance of peau d'orange (prominent hair follicle pits). Further signs include itching and nipple retraction. Even with trimodality therapy (i.e., chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and radical mastectomy) the prognosis is poor, as inflammatory breast cancer spreads early.

C) INCORRECT:

Involution of the breast parenchyma and ductal system occurs when the serum estrogen levels begin to decrease during menopause, causing the breasts to decrease in size. This patient is 55 years of age and may be perimenopausal. Although breast involution can result in benign breast cysts manifesting as painful breast lumps, it does not cause erythema, edema, or peau d'orange appearance of the skin, as seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

As the lactiferous ducts converge onto the nipple areolar complex, tumor infiltration of the ducts results in nipple retraction and discharge. While these symptoms may occur in inflammatory breast cancer, they are absent here.

E) INCORRECT:

Tumor infiltration of the breast may be associated with tightening and shortening of the suspensory ligaments (Cooper ligaments). Because these ligaments are attached to the skin, tightening results in localized retraction and dimpling of the skin that changes the normal shape and contour of the breast. It differs from the swelling and pitting of peau d'orange seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This woman has invasive carcinoma of the breast. The diffuse erythema, edema, and pitting of the skin suggest peau d'orange (skin resembling an orange peel), which supports the diagnosis of inflammatory breast cancer.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of lesions on her left arm. She first noticed them 3 months ago and they have grown larger since that time. She has not had any pain or pruritus in the area. She has a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, which was treated with mastectomy and radiation therapy 27 years ago. Since that time, she has had lymphedema of the left arm. Physical examination shows extensive edema of the left arm. There are four coalescing, firm, purple-blue nodules on the left lateral axillary region and swelling of the surrounding skin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic lymphedema is an important risk factor for development of cellulitis and other soft tissue infections, and this patient is certainly at ongoing risk of infection because of her long-standing edema. However, she lacks typical features of cellulitis (e.g., fever, pain, erythema, warmth, or tenderness), which makes an infection very unlikely. Additionally, untreated cellulitis would have progressed more quickly and the timeline of her symptoms is not consistent with this diagnosis.
Image Description:

Diffuse, poorly demarcated erythema and edema associated with small, crusted red patches are visible over the left leg.

These findings are consistent with cellulitis due to scabies infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with thrombophlebitis of a superficial vein typically present with erythema and tenderness along the vein, and the condition can cause congestion of venous vasculature distal to the thrombus. In the upper extremities, it is usually associated with intravenous catheter use. While the nodular appearance and the distribution of this patient's lesions is potentially consistent with a thrombophlebitis, pain and erythema would also be expected. Her history of chronic lymphedema suggests a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous lichen planus typically manifests as purple, polygonal, pruritic papules or plaques on the lower back, wrist, and/or ankles. Patients also present with a lattice-like network of white stripes called Wickham striae. This patient is missing common features of lichen planus, e.g., pruritus and polygonal shape. Moreover, the distribution of her lesions and the fact that they appear in conjunction with chronic lymphedema suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Ventral wrist of an adult presenting with a bilateral pruritic rash

Multiple purple-red, well-demarcated, partially confluent polygonal papules can be seen. White reticular lines (Wickham striae) are also visible on the surface of the papules.

The location and appearance of this rash are typical of lichen planus.

D) CORRECT:

Cutaneous angiosarcoma is a rare malignancy that can occur secondary to chronic lymphedema. The condition classically manifests in women who have undergone radiation therapy with subsequent lymph node sclerosis and/or mastectomy with extensive axillary lymphadenectomy, in which case it is also referred to as Stewart-Treves syndrome. Angiosarcomas typically manifest as multiple violaceous macules, papules, and/or subcutaneous nodules that develop in the area of the breast, chest wall, or upper extremity.

Due to their locally aggressive nature and tendency to metastasize early, angiosarcomas have a poor prognosis.
Image Description:

Right breast of a 56-year-old female patient after receiving radiotherapy for ductal carcinoma in situ

A purple macule measuring approximately 7 × 5 cm and resembling a hematoma is visible on the previously irradiated lower right quadrant of the right breast. Parts of the macule appear darker and indurated.

This type of cutaneous lesion combined with the patient's medical history suggest an angiosarcoma of the breast, which can occur secondary to radiation therapy. Since this is a rare condition, the clinical features seen here are easily mistaken for benign angiomas, small hematomas, or atypical telangiectasia. Histopathological investigation is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Melanoma should always be considered in the differential for a growing, asymmetric, hyperpigmented skin lesion. The amelanotic subtype can present as pink or even skin-colored nodules. While this patient is at increased risk (age, previous skin cancer) for development of melanoma, the presence of chronic lymphedema suggests a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

A solitary, red nodule on an erythematous base with slight hyperpigmentation on the bottom-right is visible.

Full-thickness excisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of amelanotic melanoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Human herpesvirus 8 can cause Kaposi sarcoma, which manifests as purple-colored or brownish skin plaques of the extremities that can progress to deeper, more nodular, and, occasionally, ulcerative, lesions. However, the lesions occur in patients who are significantly immunocompromised (e.g., AIDS, transplant recipients). The absence of severe immunocompromise in this woman makes this diagnosis highly unlikely.
Image Description:

Violaceous nodules and papules are visible beside several black-crusted plaques on the lower leg of this patient with Kaposi sarcoma.
questions.hint: A biopsy would likely show collections of slit-like anastomosing vascular channels that are lined by endothelial cells.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a rapidly growing lump in her right breast. Eight months ago, she underwent excision of a liposarcoma from the dorsum of her right forearm. Her brother was diagnosed with osteosarcoma of the maxilla at the age of 22 years. Her mother died at the age of 43 years from complications of acute myeloid leukemia. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years. Examination shows a fixed, firm mass in the right breast with axillary lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of the mass confirms the diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma. Which of the following genetic principles is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Loss of heterozygosity in tumor suppressor gene
Methylation of a previously normal gene copy
Oncogenic transformation of a previously normal gene
Exposure to an oncogenic microbial infection

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The development of malignancies in Li-Fraumeni syndrome occurs due to loss of heterozygosity in the p53 tumor suppressor gene. Affected individuals inherit one abnormal copy of the TP53 gene but only develop cancer once the second allele is somatically mutated or deleted, due to unregulated cell proliferation.

B) INCORRECT:

Methylation results in silencing of a gene copy and is the mechanism behind the genomic imprinting seen in Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome. However, this patient's diagnosis and family history suggest a hereditary syndrome in which a different genetic mechanism occurs.

C) INCORRECT:

Examples of oncogenic transformation of a previously normal gene (e.g., oncogene) include JAK-2 gene mutations (associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms), BRAF gene mutations (associated with melanoma, papillary thyroid cancer), and KRAS gene mutations (associated with colon cancer, lung cancer). Oncogenic transformation only requires a mutation in one allele of the respective proto-oncogene. This patient's diagnosis and family history suggest a hereditary syndrome in which a different genetic mechanism occurs.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic exposure to carcinogenic material can play a role in the development of individual cancer types (e.g., tobacco smoke and lung cancer, asbestos fibers and mesothelioma). However, it is unlikely to cause the constellation of malignancies seen in this patient and would not explain her family history. This patient's diagnosis and family history suggest a hereditary syndrome in which a different genetic mechanism occurs.

E) INCORRECT:

Examples of oncogenic microbial infections include HPV infection (associated with cervical cancer) and H. pylori infection (associated with gastric cancer). In this case, however, it is unlikely that this patient and her entire family was exposed to a pathogen that could cause such a variety of cancer types. This patient's diagnosis and family history suggest a hereditary syndrome due to a different genetic mechanism.
questions.hint: This patient has had multiple malignancies at an unusually early age. The history of multiple cancers in a first-degree relative suggests a hereditary component. Considering the type of cancers (sarcomas, breast cancer, leukemia) and age of onset in this family (all < 45 years), a diagnosis of Li-Fraumeni syndrome is highly likely.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman gravida 1, para 1, comes to the physician because of a lump that she noticed in her right breast. She otherwise feels well and has not had any breast pain or nipple discharge. She had right breast mastitis 10 years ago while breastfeeding but has no other history of serious illness. Palpation of the right breast shows a 3-cm firm, nontender mass with well-defined margins lateral to the right nipple. There is a dimpling of the skin overlying the mass but no rash. The left breast is normal. Mammography shows a density with calcifications in a star-shaped formation in the same location as the mass. Microscopic examination of a biopsy specimen from the breast mass shows disorganized nests of glandular cells that express E-cadherin and are surrounded by fibrous tissue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A fibroadenoma, which is the most common benign breast tumor in women, can manifest with a solitary, well-defined, nontender mass and evidence of fibrous and glandular tissue overgrowth on biopsy. However, as a benign condition, fibroadenoma is not associated with dimpling of the skin. Also, while fibroadenoma may show popcorn calcifications, calcifications in a star-shaped formation on mammography are not consistent with this diagnosis. Instead, a fibroadenoma usually appears as a smooth, polylobulated mass on mammography.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of breast tissue (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Compressed glandular spaces, i.e., epithelial component of fibroadenoma (green overlay) and stromal component of fibroadenoma (red overlay), are visible.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) INCORRECT:

Lobular carcinoma-in-situ (CIS) is usually an incidental biopsy finding. A lobular CIS would not cause a breast mass or calcifications on mammography, and tumor cells of lobular CIS typically lose their ability to express E-cadherin.

C) CORRECT:

Disorganized cords and nests of duct-like, glandular cells surrounded by a desmoplastic stroma are characteristic histological findings seen in invasive ductal carcinoma, which is the most common type of invasive breast cancer. Invasive carcinomas can manifest with a palpable breast mass and features of tumor infiltration (e.g., skin dimpling). Unlike in lobular carcinomas, tumor cells of ductal carcinomas often retain E-cadherin expression. The mammography finding of a stellate lesion occurs as a result of clustered microcalcifications of the surrounding tissue.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of biopsy specimen (H&E stain; low magnification) from a mobile breast lump in 64-year-old female patient

Main image: At low magnification, a dense irregular mass (purple/pink) with poorly circumscribed borders can be seen infiltrating the mature adipose tissue of the breast (white). The mass is composed of disorganized tubular formations of the carcinoma (dark blue/basophilic staining) and surrounding collagenous connective tissue (pink/eosinophilic staining; also known as “desmoplastic stroma”).

Top right inset: very low magnification overview indicating the location of the main image on the specimen

D) INCORRECT:

Paget disease of the breast classically manifests with an erythematous, scaly rash involving the nipple. This patient, however, does not have a rash, and calcifications in a star-shaped formation on mammography are not consistent with this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

An invasive lobular carcinoma, which is the second most common type of invasive breast carcinoma, can manifest with a palpable breast mass and calcifications on mammography. However, a biopsy would show orderly rows of monomorphic neoplastic cells in a “single file” pattern without duct formation. In addition, a desmoplastic (fibrous) response is often absent and tumor cells of invasive lobular carcinomas typically lose their ability to express E-cadherin.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a breast tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain; 40x magnification)

Infiltrating malignant cells can be seen as single cells, narrow chords (examples indicated by green overlay), and characteristic single-file formations (examples indicated by blue overlay). The tumor cells are seen growing between distorted ductuli (D) and lobuli (L), surrounded by conspicuously pale connective tissue. There is no tubule formation of the tumor (as is commonly seen in other types of adenocarcinomas of the breast).

This is the typical appearance of invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast.

Click on the microscope icon (at the top) to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

F) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive form of invasive breast cancer that classically manifests with an erythematous tender breast, peau d'orange appearance (due to dermal lymphatic invasion), and breast engorgement rather than a palpable breast mass. Peau d'orange appearance is characterized by diffuse breast skin dimpling and is different from the isolated dimpling of skin overlying the breast mass seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Dimpling (puckering) of the skin overlying the breast mass indicates tightening and shortening of the suspensory ligaments (Cooper ligaments) as a result of tumor infiltration.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a growing lump in the right breast that she first noticed 1 month ago. Physical examination of the right breast shows a 3.5-cm firm, fixed mass in the right upper quadrant. There is dimpling of the overlying skin. Mammography shows a mass with poorly-defined margins and microcalcifications. Immunohistochemical analysis of a biopsy specimen from the mass shows malignant cells that stain negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors and positive for human epidermal growth factor receptor 2. The drug that most specifically targets this patient's tumor is also used in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alemtuzumab is approved for disease-modifying multiple sclerosis therapy and can also be used in the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Trastuzumab, however, is not indicated for multiple sclerosis.

B) CORRECT:

Overexpression of ERBB2 is found in up to 25% of gastric cancers and 15–20% of breast cancers. ERBB2-positive cancers have been associated with a poor prognosis due to more aggressive tumor growth and higher recurrence rates. However, the introduction of drugs that target ERBB2, such as trastuzumab, has improved the prognosis. Trastuzumab blocks this receptor, which leads to growth arrest and subsequent apoptosis of cancer cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Bevacizumab is used in the treatment of colorectal cancer, renal cell carcinoma, non-small cell lung cancer and neovascular age-related macular degeneration. It binds to and neutralizes vascular endothelial growth factor, thereby preventing angiogenesis and causing growth arrest of (tumor) cells. Although bevacizumab is sometimes used off-label as combination therapy in treatment of metastatic breast cancer, it would not specifically target this patient's tumor cells. Trastuzumab, on the other hand, is not indicated for colorectal cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Raloxifene, a selective estrogen receptor modulator, can be used in the prevention and treatment of osteoporosis in patients with contraindications to bisphosphonates or those who also benefit from breast cancer prophylaxis. However, it is not approved for breast cancer treatment. Trastuzumab, on the other hand, is not indicated for osteoporosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Rituximab is a biological agent that is used as a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug. It is also indicated for treatment of immune thrombocytopenic purpura, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and symptomatic Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia. Trastuzumab, however, has no role in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.
questions.hint: Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits tumor growth by selectively binding to the human epidermal growth factor receptor ERBB2. It targets cells that overexpress this receptor, such as this patient's breast cancer cells.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician 2 weeks after noticing a lump in her left breast. Examination of the left breast shows a firm, nontender mass close to the nipple. Mammography shows an irregular calcified mass. A core needle biopsy shows invasive ductal carcinoma. Genetic analysis of this patient's cancer cells is most likely to show overexpression of which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The ERBB2 gene encodes for a growth factor receptor with intracellular tyrosine kinase activity and is overexpressed in about 20% of breast cancers. ERBB2 overexpression is typically associated with a more aggressive clinical course and worse prognosis, although the ERBB2 receptor can be directly targeted by trastuzumab. This patient's core needle specimen should also undergo immunohistochemical staining for estrogen and progesterone receptor status (positive in 70% of cases) to further delineate tumor grade and guide treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutations of PTEN, a tumor suppressor gene, are associated with breast, prostate, and endometrial cancer. However, cancer develops due to a loss of function of the encoded protein, not an overexpression of PTEN.

C) INCORRECT:

KRAS is a proto-oncogene that is involved in cellular growth regulation. Mutations in KRAS are typically found in colon, lung, and pancreatic cancers, but they are not associated with breast cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Mutations of TP53, a tumor suppressor gene, lead to uncontrolled cell proliferation and are thus associated with many types of cancer (e.g., sarcomas, breast cancer, leukemias). However, cancer develops due to a loss of function of the encoded p53 protein, not an overexpression of TP53.

E) INCORRECT:

BCR-ABL is a fusion gene resulting from a reciprocal translocation between chromosome 9 and chromosome 22 (t(9;22)), also known as the Philadelphia chromosome). It encodes for a nonreceptor tyrosine kinase that, as opposed to other tyrosine kinases, is continuously activated, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation. A Philadelphia translocation is most commonly found in chronic myeloid leukemia; it is not associated with breast cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

BRCA-2 is a tumor suppressor gene involved in DNA repair processes. Autosomal dominant inherited mutations of this gene strongly predispose to development of several cancers, especially breast cancer and ovarian cancer. However, this increased risk is due to a loss of function of the encoded DNA repair protein, not an overexpression of BRCA-2.
questions.hint: This gene encodes an epidermal growth factor receptor involved in regulating cell growth and differentiation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine bone mineral density screening. She does not have any children. Menopause was at age 55. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 48 years. She has hypertension for which she takes ramipril. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry at the femoral neck shows a T-score of -2.7 SD. The physician considers treatment with raloxifene. This medication would put her at increased risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Osteoporosis in postmenopausal women is most commonly due to estrogen deficiency. Estrogen physiologically prevents bone breakdown by stimulating osteoblasts and inhibiting osteoclasts. Raloxifene prevents bone resorption by acting as an agonist on estrogen receptors in the bone. At the same time, it acts as an estrogen antagonist in the breast and endometrium. The most severe adverse effects of raloxifene are thromboembolic events, such as deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and retinal vein thrombosis. Raloxifene is therefore contraindicated in women with a history of or current venous thromboembolic disorders.

B) INCORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux is a common side effect of oral bisphosphonate treatment. Bisphosphonates are usually the first-line treatment in osteoporosis because they effectively prevent bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclasts. Raloxifene, however, is unlikely to cause gastroesophageal reflux.

C) INCORRECT:

An increased risk for skin infections (e.g., cellulitis) is associated with the use of denosumab. Denosumab is a treatment option in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis who have contraindications or do not respond to other treatments. Raloxifene, however, is not known to cause cellulitis.

D) INCORRECT:

An increased risk of breast cancer is associated with the use of hormone replacement therapy (HRT). Although this patient's positive family history and increased estrogen exposure (nulliparous, late menopause) do place her at increased risk for breast cancer, raloxifene acts as an estrogen antagonist in breast tissue, which decreases the risk of breast cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Mandibular osteonecrosis is a rare but serious adverse effect of bisphosphonates. Bisphosphonates are usually the first-line treatment in osteoporosis because they effectively prevent bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclasts. Raloxifene, however, is not known to cause mandibular osteonecrosis.

F) INCORRECT:

The use of tamoxifen or unopposed estrogen increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia. Raloxifene, however, acts as an estrogen antagonist in the uterus, which decreases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia.

G) INCORRECT:

Hypercholesterolemia would not be expected in treatment with raloxifene. In fact, raloxifene has been shown to decrease serum cholesterol.
questions.hint: Raloxifene, a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), is the drug of choice for osteoporosis in postmenopausal women who are at an increased risk of developing breast cancer (in this case, the history of breast cancer at a young age in a first-degree relative and nulliparity increase this patient's risk). An adverse effect that is due to its estrogenic activity should be considered.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of right breast pain that is associated with itchiness. Her right breast has become larger over the past 2 weeks. She has not had any nipple discharge. She has hypertension and vulvar lichen sclerosus. Her current medications are enalapril and topical clobetasol propionate. Her temperature is 37.9°C (98.9°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 127/85 mm Hg. A photograph of the patient's chest is shown. The right breast is warm and tender to palpation. There is right-sided nontender axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An acute onset (< 6 months) of edema and erythema that involves at least one-third of the breast with peau d’orange, nipple retraction, and axillary lymphadenopathy raises suspicion for inflammatory breast cancer (IBC). Blood-tinged nipple discharge is also a common finding in patients with IBC. For patients with clinical findings of IBC, a core needle biopsy is indicated to confirm the diagnosis, and if invasive carcinoma is found, two full-thickness skin punch biopsies should be obtained. IBC is a rare but aggressive carcinoma, and most patients have metastatic disease at the time of initial presentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Mastitis manifests with tenderness, warmth, erythema, and edema of the affected breast, as well as reactive lymphadenopathy, all of which are seen in this patient. However, mastitis typically develops in women who are breastfeeding, most commonly within a month postpartum, making this diagnosis unlikely. Furthermore, patients with mastitis present with flu-like symptoms such as fever, chills, and malaise, none of which are seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Phyllodes tumor of the breast most commonly affects women between 40 and 50 years of age and can have a phase of rapid growth. In contrast to this patient's presentation, however, phyllodes tumor manifests as a painless, smooth, multinodular lump in the breast. Furthermore, this tumor does not typically cause breast inflammation, which this patient has.

D) INCORRECT:

Intraductal papilloma is a benign condition that can be seen in women between 40 and 50 years of age. It manifests as a nontender palpable mass close to or behind the nipple or areola, in contrast to the findings in this patient, and it is the most common cause of bloody or serous nipple discharge. Furthermore, this condition does not typically cause breast inflammation.

E) INCORRECT:

Paget disease of the breast can manifest with erythema, pruritus, and nipple retraction, all of which are seen here. However, these findings are typically limited to the nipple and areola and do not involve the entire breast.
Image Description:

An erythematous, scaling rash with irregular borders and erosion of the nipple is visible on the left breast of a female patient. The pathology extends beyond the areola region.

These findings are typical of Paget's disease of the breast, a rare type of ductal carcinoma that is often accompanied by nipple discharge. Age-appropriate imaging and biopsy are required for diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

A fibroadenoma typically manifests as a solitary, well-defined, nontender mobile mass, unlike what is seen in this patient. Fibroadenomas are more common among women < 35 years of age and the tumor size is affected by estrogen levels (e.g., tumor size increases during pregnancy or before menstruation). Furthermore, fibroadenoma does not typically manifest with inflammatory signs such as warmth, erythema, and edema.

G) INCORRECT:

Mammary duct ectasia most commonly affects middle-aged women and can manifest with breast tenderness and nipple inversion, both of which are seen here. However, unlike the diffuse tenderness and erythema seen in this patient, the findings in duct ectasia are localized to the area under the nipple and are often associated with a palpable mass. Furthermore, patients with duct ectasia characteristically present with greenish or bloody discharge from the affected nipple.
questions.hint: The photograph shows an edematous, erythematous right breast with noticeable hair follicles, resulting in an orange peel (peau d’orange) appearance, which is highly characteristic of this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an itchy rash and a burning sensation affecting the area around her left nipple. Her symptoms have progressively worsened since she first discovered the rash 4 months ago. Ibuprofen and over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream provided no relief. Medical history is unremarkable. Her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 65 years. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the rash is shown. Physical examination shows no nipple discharge, palpable breast masses, or axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform KOH test on skin scrapings
Perform punch biopsy of the lesion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral dicloxacillin therapy is indicated for the treatment of skin infections such as erysipelas, which manifests with a sharply demarcated erythematous lesion, similar to what is seen here. However, this patient does not have other common features of erysipelas (e.g., fever and a more acute onset), making this diagnosis less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

KOH testing of skin scrapings is used in the diagnosis of dermatophyte infections, which can manifest with an itchy, erythematous, scaly lesion, similar to what is seen here. However, with time, lesions of dermatophyte infections typically develop into round plaques with central clearing and raised borders, which is not seen here. Moreover, an isolated lesion around the nipple is unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Imaging of the breast is indicated in patients with PDB to exclude associated abnormalities (e.g., masses, architectural distortions) and synchronous breast malignancies. However, in patients older than 30 years of age, like this one, bilateral mammography rather than ultrasonography of the breast is indicated. Ultrasonography of the breast is usually indicated as the initial imaging in patients younger than 30 years of age and/or to guide core biopsy of any associated abnormalities.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with clinical findings suggestive of PDB, a punch biopsy of the lesion should be performed, and the visualization of Paget cells on microscopy confirms the diagnosis. Patients with PDB should also undergo bilateral mammography to exclude associated abnormalities (e.g., masses, architectural distortions) and underlying or synchronous breast malignancies (e.g., ductal carcinoma in situ or invasive ductal carcinoma). The treatment for PDB can vary depending on these mammographic findings but always includes resection of the lesion and nipple-areolar complex.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical calcineurin inhibitors (e.g., tacrolimus) can be used in the management of atopic nipple eczema, which manifests as an itchy, erythematous, scaly lesion around the nipple and areolar region, similar to what is seen here. However, this patient experienced no symptom relief with topical corticosteroid therapy (the mainstay of treatment for atopic eczema), making this diagnosis unlikely. This patient's worsening symptoms despite treatment with topical steroids should raise concern for PDB; a different step is more appropriate.
questions.hint: This patient's itchy, erythematous, scaly rash on the areola should raise concern for Paget disease of the breast (PDB).

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive enlargement and pain in her left breast. Over-the-counter analgesics and cold compresses have provided minimal relief. Medical history is remarkable for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease well controlled with inhaled albuterol as needed. Her last menstrual period was 2 years ago. The patient lives alone and has no children. She smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit 4 years ago. She drinks two to three glasses of wine on weekends. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a firm, tender, edematous left breast with diffuse purple skin discoloration and nipple flattening. Blood-tinged discharge can be expressed from the left nipple. Examination of the right breast shows no abnormalities. There is tender axillary lymphadenopathy on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the axillary lymph nodes

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The initial diagnostic workup of patients with suspected IBC should include mammography of both breasts and a core needle biopsy of the affected breast, which, if invasive carcinoma is shown, confirms the diagnosis of IBC. Mammography is usually followed by ultrasonography of the breast and regional lymph nodes to evaluate for metastases. In patients with confirmed IBC, skin punch biopsies should also be obtained to assess for dermal lymphovascular invasion. Clinical staging should be concluded by screening for distant metastases and receptor testing.

B) INCORRECT:

A fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the axillary lymph nodes is indicated in patients with a confirmed diagnosis of IBC who have palpable or suspicious lymph nodes. Results are used to establish accurate clinical staging and prognosis. Although this patient's axillary lymphadenopathy raises suspicion for lymph node metastases, a different diagnostic step is indicated first.

C) INCORRECT:

An excisional skin biopsy is indicated in cases of suspected skin cancer (e.g., basal cell cancer, melanoma) but not in the diagnostic workup of IBC. In this patient, a core needle biopsy of the breast should be performed, which, if invasive carcinoma is shown, establishes the diagnosis of IBC. On further evaluation, at least two skin punch biopsies should also be obtained and examined for dermal lymphovascular invasion, which is characteristic of IBC.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest (typically followed by abdominal and pelvic CT scans) is indicated in patients with a confirmed diagnosis of IBC to assess for distant metastases, which are seen in the majority of cases at initial diagnosis. Although this patient might require a CT scan of the chest during further evaluation, a different diagnostic step is more appropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Cytology of nipple discharge is not routinely indicated in patients with suspected breast malignancy because it has little diagnostic value. Distinguishing malignant cells from crenated or apoptotic cells is technically challenging. In addition, cancerous ducts do not necessarily excrete malignant cells into the nipple discharge. Furthermore, even if cytology reveals malignant cells, localization of the tumor remains difficult.
questions.hint: This nulliparous patient with a history of late-onset menopause presents with a tender, enlarged, and erythematous breast, nipple flattening, blood-tinged nipple discharge, and axillary lymphadenopathy, all of which are consistent with inflammatory breast cancer (IBC).

questions.text: A 58-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. Her medical history is remarkable for hypertension. Menopause occurred 2 years ago. A colonoscopy and mammography performed 1 year ago showed no abnormalities. Current medications include hormone replacement therapy with estrogen and progestin, and enalapril. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 12 years. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 81 kg (179 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.2°C (97.2°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 137/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a nontender, firm, nonmobile 1 x 2 cm mass in the right axilla. The remainder of the examination, including palpation of both breasts and the left axilla, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Breast MRI is recommended for the evaluation of axillary lymphadenopathy in patients with a high risk of breast cancer whose previous imaging tests have failed to detect any breast masses. This patient has not been investigated yet, so breast MRI would not be appropriate at this time.

B) INCORRECT:
