A CT scan of the chest is appropriate in the assessment of patients with suspected lung cancer. Although this patient's smoking history increases her risk of developing lung cancer, she currently presents with axillary lymphadenopathy, which should primarily raise concern for breast cancer, rather than lung cancer. A CT scan of the chest is not indicated in the initial diagnostic workup of a patient with suspected breast cancer.

A low-dose CT scan of the chest is recommended annually for screening of lung cancer in patients aged 50–80 years with a ≥ 20-pack-year smoking history. This patient has smoked for 12 years; a CT scan of the chest is therefore not recommended as a screening modality.

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up could be recommended in a patient with axillary lymphadenopathy whose workup findings support a self-limiting or benign cause of lymphadenopathy (e.g., viral infection). The nontender, firm, nonmobile lymphadenopathy raises concern for malignancy in this patient, so a different approach is more appropriate at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Lymph node biopsy, rather than excision, is used to assess for breast cancer in patients with axillary lymphadenopathy without a clear etiology. Lymph node biopsy is performed together with another diagnostic procedure.

E) CORRECT:

In a woman with axillary lymphadenopathy of unknown etiology in whom there is a concern for breast malignancy, mammography and axillary lymph node biopsy should be performed even when there is no palpable breast mass. If the histology of the biopsy confirms the presence of adenocarcinoma or poorly differentiated carcinoma without a detectable breast mass on mammography, occult breast cancer should be suspected. A breast MRI can be performed to further search for the location of the primary tumor.
questions.hint: This patient's mass is consistent with axillary lymphadenopathy, which should raise concern for breast cancer in a postmenopausal woman. Furthermore, she has multiple risk factors for breast cancer (advanced age, nulliparity, female sex, hormone therapy, history of smoking, obesity, late menopause).

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the office because of a lump in her left breast that she first noticed 2 weeks ago. Her medical history is unremarkable. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Her aunt was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at the age of 55 years. The patient has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 9 years and drinks one to two alcoholic beverages weekly. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (139 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg. Palpation of the left breast discloses a firm, rigid, nontender mass in the upper outer quadrant; the overlying skin shows no abnormalities. There is no nipple discharge. Examination of the right breast shows no abnormalities and axillary lymph nodes are not palpable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

BRCA gene testing is recommended for evaluating breast cancer in patients with a family history of breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer, or in some patients after breast cancer (e.g., triple-negative or bilateral breast cancer) is diagnosed. Although this patient has a family history of ovarian cancer, testing is only indicated after the diagnosis is made and if a first-degree relative is affected.

B) CORRECT:

Breast ultrasound is the most appropriate next step when evaluating a palpable breast mass in women < 30 years of age. Premenopausal women < 30 years of age often have dense breast tissue, which decreases the diagnostic accuracy of mammography in these individuals. Furthermore, ultrasound imaging does not expose the patient to ionizing radiation, unlike mammography. Breast ultrasonography helps distinguish solid lesions from benign cysts, as well as evaluate axillary, supraclavicular, and infraclavicular lymph nodes. If imaging reveals signs of malignancy (e.g., mass irregularity, heterogenicity, spiculated margin), mammography, in addition to ultrasound, can be performed and a biopsy of the lesion is indicated.

For women between 30 and 39 years of age, both mammography and ultrasound can be used; mammography is the recommended imaging modality in women ≥ 40 years of age.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated in the case of a benign breast lesion, such as fibroadenoma, which is the most common breast tumor in women < 35 years of age. Benign breast lesions are typically soft, well-defined, and mobile, unlike this patient's firm, rigid, and nontender mass. This approach is appropriate only after the diagnosis is established.

D) INCORRECT:

Core needle biopsy (CNB) is used to assess a palpable breast mass with findings that suggest malignancy (e.g., firm, rigid, nontender mass). Because CNB has high sensitivity and specificity, it is used to evaluate the extent of the tumor, as well as its histology and receptor profile. Although CNB is part of the workup of breast lumps, it is performed after imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

Mammography is used for the evaluation of palpable breast masses in women ≥ 40 years of age. This screening modality is also recommended for breast cancer screening in this age group (i.e., ≥ 40 years) because it can detect the majority of malignancies and lesions ∼ 2 years before they are clinically evident. However, this imaging modality is less sensitive in younger patients with high breast density.
Image Description:

Mammography (right breast; craniocaudal view)

A mass (circled) with suspicious features, including high density and indistinct margins, is visible in the posterior third of the breast.
questions.hint: A palpable breast mass requires further assessment regardless of the clinical features of the mass and the patient's age.

Appearance: appears well; no acute distress

Pulmonary: clear lung fields
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Chest: normal, symmetrical breasts with no masses on palpation; no nipple discharge or overlying skin changes; no axillary lymphadenopathy
Pelvic: mild vulvovaginal atrophy; no cervical tenderness; uterus normal in size and shape; no adnexal masses or tenderness 

Diagnostic Studies
mammography: extremely dense breast tissue throughout; one group of clustered, amorphous microcalcifications in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intraductal papilloma mainly affects individuals between 30 and 50 years of age and mammography findings may include calcifications, but the condition typically manifests with a palpable, retroareolar mass that is well-defined and has regular borders on imaging.

B) CORRECT:

Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is often detected early on mammography screening as grouped, amorphous microcalcifications. In contrast, lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) does not typically manifest with calcifications and is difficult to detect on standard breast imaging. Although DCIS and LCIS are technically considered nonmalignant because they do not cross the basement membrane, both increase the risk of invasive breast cancer. Mammography findings that raise suspicion for malignancy include grouped microcalcifications, an irregularly shaped mass with indistinct borders and spiculated margins, and a high breast density. See “Features of breast mass on mammography” table.
Image Description:

Mammography (right breast; mediolateral oblique view)

A high-density mass (green overlay) with an indistinct margin and containing microcalcifications (examples indicated by red overlay) projects in the upper breast.

The features of this lesion are highly suspicious for malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Sclerosing adenosis is a common benign lesion of the breast and may manifest with cyclic mastalgia and calcifications on mammography, but the calcifications are typically diffuse rather than clustered.

D) INCORRECT:

Mondor disease of the breast may manifest with noncyclical mastalgia, but the typical manifestation is the sudden onset of a tender, cord-like induration, which corresponds to a superficial tubular structure that has a beaded appearance on mammography.

E) INCORRECT:

Fat necrosis of the breast can resemble malignancy and manifest with grouped calcifications on mammography. However, the calcifications typically have a coarse rim or eggshell appearance, and the findings are frequently associated with a spiculated mass or fluid-filled oil cyst. Moreover, fat necrosis often involves skin changes (e.g., reaction, erythema, and ecchymosis) and a history of trauma, surgery, or radiation of the breast.
questions.hint: Risk factors associated with this condition include nulliparity, obesity, early menarche, and late menopause.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman comes for a routine office visit and asks if her next mammogram is necessary. She has been compliant with her annual mammograms since age 50 and is due for her next one in a month.
Her medical history consists of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, hypothyroidism, osteoarthritis, and congestive heart failure, which developed after a recent acute myocardial infarction. She notes that the heart failure is affecting her activities of daily living and that she cannot walk up a flight of stairs without feeling short of breath. She states that her mother died suddenly at age 72 after a heart attack.
On physical examination, her breasts are small, with no lumps or nodules on palpation. Her nipple-areola complexes are normal to inspection and to palpation. The rest of her physical examination is normal.
Routine laboratory testing shows a mildly elevated glucose level, but other values are within normal limits.
What is the best evidence-based recommendation to give this patient regarding breast cancer screening?

choices.text: Increase the interval between screening mammograms to 3 years
Switch from annual screening mammograms to monthly breast self-examinations
Switch from annual screening mammography to annual MRI of the breast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There are no data regarding the utility of triennial mammography.

The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force states that the “current evidence is insufficient to assess the benefits and harms of screening mammography in women 75 years or older.”

B) CORRECT:

Data regarding the effects of screening mammography in women ≥70 years of age are limited, but the only randomized trial of such women showed no benefit. The National Cancer Institute estimated that two additional deaths from breast cancer would be prevented per 1000 women screened from the age of 70 to 74, with little additional benefit gained from extending screening beyond age 74. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force states that the “current evidence is insufficient to assess the benefits and harms of screening mammography in women 75 years or older.”

Experts agree that breast-cancer screening is not indicated in women who have serious coexisting illnesses and a life expectancy of less than 5 to 10 years. This includes mammography, MRI, and breast self-examination.

Key learning point: The age at which screening mammography can be discontinued is approximately 75 years of age. Screening mammography can also be discontinued in women with a life expectancy of less than 5 to 10 years.

C) INCORRECT:

Experts agree that breast-cancer screening is not indicated in women who have serious coexisting illnesses and a life expectancy of less than 5 to 10 years. This includes mammography, MRI, and breast self-examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Experts agree that breast-cancer screening is not indicated in women who have serious coexisting illnesses and a life expectancy of less than 5 to 10 years. This includes mammography, MRI, and breast self-examination.

E) INCORRECT:

The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force states that the “current evidence is insufficient to assess the benefits and harms of screening mammography in women 75 years or older.”

Experts agree that breast-cancer screening is not indicated in women who have serious coexisting illnesses and a life expectancy of less than 5 to 10 years. This includes mammography, MRI, and breast self-examination.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman reports a 3-week history of shooting pains from her left axilla, associated with a growing lump. She has not had any recent infections, weight loss, fevers, or night sweats.
Physical examination reveals no skin breaks or erythema of the left arm. She has a 2-cm mobile nontender lymph node in the left axilla but no other palpable abnormalities. A biopsy of the node reveals adenocarcinoma.
What is the most appropriate next step to determine the diagnosis in this case?

choices.text: CT of the chest with intravenous contrast
Combination positron emission tomography and CT

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT of the chest would be used to evaluate for adenocarcinoma of the lung. However, this cancer does not typically metastasize to the axillary lymph nodes unless it is very advanced.

B) INCORRECT:

Combination positron emission tomography and CT would be appropriate for a new lymphoma diagnosis or if the clinical history indicated a primary lung mass. However, in this case, the biopsy demonstrated adenocarcinoma in an axillary lymph node.

C) CORRECT:

The presence of axillary lymphadenopathy — without any other lymphadenopathy — in a patient with adenocarcinoma should prompt evaluation of the breast. Not all breast tumors are easily palpable, and many may not even be detected on a mammogram. However, mammography is the usual method of assessing the breast as a site of primary tumor in women with axillary nodes showing adenocarcinoma. MRI may also be considered, as it is thought to be more sensitive in the detection of breast cancer associated with mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes.

Key learning point: In women, appropriate evaluation of adenocarcinoma in an axillary lymph node includes bilateral diagnostic mammography, with or without ultrasound of the breast.
Image Description:

Lymph is drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct primarily drains the upper right side of the body (green overlay). The thoracic duct is responsible for draining the rest of the body.

Testicular tumors do not typically disseminate to scrotal lymph nodes, because the two organs have separate lymphatic systems: testes drain to the para-aortic nodes and the scrotum drains to superficial inguinal nodes.

D) INCORRECT:

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy would be indicated for evaluation of esophageal, gastric, or colonic primary tumors. However, none of these cancers typically metastasize to the axillary lymph nodes unless they are very advanced.

E) INCORRECT:

Genetic testing for breast cancer susceptibility genes (BRCA1 and 2) is indicated in young premenopausal women with breast cancer but would be premature in a patient who does not yet have an established diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man reports that he noticed a lump in his left breast several months ago. Physical examination confirms the presence of an easily palpable, hard, fixed, 2-cm mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast, adjacent to the nipple. The patient has no pain, tenderness, discharge from the nipple, or constitutional symptoms.
In addition to mammography, what is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Schedule CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis
Perform testing for breast cancer susceptibility genes 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A chest radiograph would not provide useful information at this time.

B) CORRECT:

Male breast cancer is rare but is associated with substantial morbidity and mortality. Physical examination is the most important initial diagnostic tool. In cases of easily palpable, suspicious masses, a core biopsy for tissue diagnosis should not be delayed. A fine-needle aspiration is a reasonable alternative. However, many experts consider it less ideal because false-negative results are common.

Other than mammography, no further breast imaging is needed in this setting, although ultrasound and possibly MRI can provide additional diagnostic information.

Key learning point: In addition to mammography, the most appropriate diagnostic test for an older man with an easily palpable breast mass is core biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Staging studies, including CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, might be required if a malignancy is confirmed but would be premature at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Although many breast cancers in men express estrogen and androgen receptors, there is no role for measurement of estradiol or testosterone levels in diagnosis of an indeterminate breast mass.

E) INCORRECT:

Genetic counseling, along with testing for breast cancer susceptibility genes 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2), is useful for men who have a breast cancer diagnosis, especially those with a family history of breast cancer.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents for follow-up of an inflamed right breast. Two weeks earlier, she presented with redness, swelling, and tenderness of the entire right breast and has since completed 10 days of oral clindamycin 300 mg three times daily. She notes that her symptoms have not improved.
On physical examination, the entire right breast is inflamed, with peau d’orange change (figure). There are no palpable lymph nodes or associated nipple changes.
Which one of the following next steps is most likely to provide a diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Biopsy of the inflamed breast tissue
A therapeutic trial of intravenous vancomycin twice daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although obtaining breast imaging (usually mammography and ultrasound, occasionally MRI) is part of the staging procedure of breast cancer, inflammatory breast cancer is often not detected by these imaging modalities and will therefore not be diagnostic.

B) CORRECT:

Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive type of breast cancer that often manifests with acute swelling, redness, itching, pain, tenderness, and warmth. Nipple retraction and skin changes can occur. It can mimic acute mastitis. A distinct lump can sometimes be felt but not in most cases. Inflammatory breast cancer occurs when cancer cells obstruct lymphatic vessels in breast tissue, leading to edema and inflammation. The only reliable diagnostic tool is biopsy.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for a woman with an inflamed breast that has not responded to initial oral antibiotics is biopsy of the inflamed breast tissue.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeating another course of antibiotics, even with intravenous antibiotics like vancomycin, when the first course has failed will not provide a diagnosis, is unlikely to treat a patient who has already received adequate antibiotics, and may further delay diagnosis of a life-threatening disease. It is therefore not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Although obtaining breast imaging (usually mammography and ultrasound, occasionally MRI) is part of the staging procedure of breast cancer, inflammatory breast cancer is often not detected by these imaging modalities and will therefore not be diagnostic.

E) INCORRECT:

Although obtaining breast imaging (usually mammography and ultrasound, occasionally MRI) is part of the staging procedure of breast cancer, inflammatory breast cancer is often not detected by these imaging modalities and will therefore not be diagnostic.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old postmenopausal woman with a history of obesity reports 2 months of irregular vaginal bleeding. Ten years ago, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and treated successfully with surgery, radiation therapy, and tamoxifen. She has no family history of breast or gynecologic cancer. Physical examination, including a pelvic examination, is normal. Her most recent Pap test, performed one year ago, was normal, with negative testing for human papillomavirus.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s evaluation?

choices.text: Operative dilatation and curettage of the endometrium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Pap test is most useful for cervical cancer screening and is not used to evaluate endometrial cancer. This patient is up to date on her cervical cancer screening; her next routine screening would not be due for another 4 years. The recent negative result also makes cervical cancer an unlikely cause of her postmenopausal bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiographic imaging could be considered as an alternative to endometrial biopsy in this case, but the imaging should be done via transvaginal ultrasound rather than CT or MRI of the pelvis. Although an ultrasound would be acceptable, an endometrial biopsy is typically preferred because it is a simple procedure with a high sensitivity and provides tissue diagnosis. If an ultrasound is pursued, then the thickness of the endometrium is used to assess the risk of endometrial cancer. Typically, an endometrial thickness of <4 mm in patients with postmenopausal bleeding reliably excludes endometrial cancer; the negative predictive value approaches 99%. Patients who have an endometrial stripe >4 mm require further evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Operative dilatation and curettage is unnecessarily invasive and is not indicated for the initial evaluation of a woman with postmenopausal bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

Irregular vaginal bleeding in a postmenopausal woman should raise concern for endometrial cancer. Risk factors for endometrial cancer include obesity, polycystic ovary syndrome, use of estrogen replacement therapy, use of tamoxifen, older age, and certain familial genetic disorders such as Lynch syndrome. Endometrial cancer is most often diagnosed in the sixth decade of life; complex endometrial hyperplasia can increase the risk.

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen-receptor modulator. Although its primary therapeutic effect in breast cancer treatment is due to its antiestrogenic properties, this drug also has modest estrogenic activity. In standard doses, it can be associated with endometrial proliferation, hyperplasia, polyp formation, and uterine carcinoma and sarcoma. Screening for endometrial cancer with routine transvaginal ultrasonography, endometrial biopsy, or both has not been shown to be effective in asymptomatic patients using tamoxifen.

Postmenopausal women who experience vaginal bleeding and have a history of tamoxifen use should undergo evaluation with in-office endometrial biopsy.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to evaluate a postmenopausal woman who was treated with tamoxifen for several years and now presents with irregular vaginal bleeding is an in-office endometrial biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Radiographic imaging could be considered as an alternative to endometrial biopsy in this case, but the imaging should be done via transvaginal ultrasound rather than CT or MRI of the pelvis. Although an ultrasound would be acceptable, an endometrial biopsy is typically preferred because it is a simple procedure with a high sensitivity and provides tissue diagnosis. If an ultrasound is pursued, then the thickness of the endometrium is used to assess the risk of endometrial cancer. Typically, an endometrial thickness of <4 mm in patients with postmenopausal bleeding reliably excludes endometrial cancer; the negative predictive value approaches 99%. Patients who have an endometrial stripe >4 mm require further evaluation.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman seeks advice about screening for breast cancer, noting that her sister was diagnosed at age 40 and her mother at age 42. She herself reached menarche at age 13 and has no children. She feels well and engages in regular physical activity.
Physical examination, including inspection and palpation of the breasts, is unremarkable.
The patient’s estimated lifetime risk of breast cancer is 31.3%, according to a validated risk-prediction tool. She does not consider bilateral prophylactic mastectomy with breast reconstruction to be a viable option for herself at this time.
Which one of the following screening strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Annual mammography with annual MRI of the breasts
Annual MRI with annual ultrasound of the breasts

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Annual ultrasound is not a recommended screening modality, either alone or in combination with mammography

B) INCORRECT:

The American Cancer Society recommends MRI screening for individuals with a lifetime breast cancer risk of ≥ 20% based on family history and for those with mutations in the breast cancer susceptibility genes (BRCA1 and 2). Annual mammography is useful in detecting microcalcifications due to ductal carcinoma in situ. A different screening strategy is more appropriate in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Risk-prediction models, such as the Gail model or BRCAPRO, take into account the patient’s family history — and, for the Gail model, the patient’s menstrual history, pregnancy history, and history of any breast biopsies — to provide an estimate of the patient’s 5-year and lifetime risk of a diagnosis of breast cancer. A calculated risk of 31.3% is considered high. Many women in a similar situation opt for mastectomy and breast reconstruction, rather than deal with the persistent uncertainty of missing an early breast cancer because the detection methods are suboptimal.

The American Cancer Society recommends both MRI and mammography for women with a lifetime breast cancer risk of at least 20% to 25% on the basis of family history and for those with mutations in the breast cancer susceptibility genes (BRCA1 and 2). Both screening tests should be performed annually, as MRI has better sensitivity in young women with increased mammographic density, and mammography is superior to MRI in detecting microcalcifications associated with ductal carcinoma in situ.

BRCA testing should be offered to the patient’s affected family members. Even if no mutation is found in the family, the patient should begin screening immediately, as screening is recommended 5 to 10 years before the youngest age at which breast cancer was diagnosed in a family member.

Annual ultrasound is not a recommended screening modality; neither alone nor in combination with mammography.

Key learning point: The best approach to breast cancer screening for young women who have a lifetime breast cancer risk of 20% or higher is annual MRI in addition to annual mammography.

D) INCORRECT:

The American Cancer Society recommends both MRI and mammography for women with a lifetime breast cancer risk of at least 20% to 25% on the basis of family history and for those with mutations in the breast cancer susceptibility genes (BRCA1 and 2). Both screening tests should be performed annually, as MRI has better sensitivity in young women with increased mammographic density, and mammography is superior to MRI in detecting microcalcifications associated with ductal carcinoma in situ.

E) INCORRECT:

The American Cancer Society recommends both MRI and mammography for women with a lifetime breast cancer risk of at least 20% to 25% on the basis of family history and for those with mutations in the breast cancer susceptibility genes (BRCA1 and 2). Both screening tests should be performed annually, as MRI has better sensitivity in young women with increased mammographic density, and mammography is superior to MRI in detecting microcalcifications associated with ductal carcinoma in situ. Annual ultrasound is not a recommended screening modality; neither alone nor in combination with mammography.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old premenopausal woman presents with a small lump in her left breast that was found during a routine clinical visit. Physical examination shows that both breasts are normal-sized, with no palpable axillary lymph nodes. A core needle biopsy reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma that is estrogen-receptor-positive, progesterone-receptor-positive, and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2–negative. The tumor measures 1.0 cm in its greatest dimension; sentinel-lymph-node biopsy is negative. A breast-cancer recurrence score is calculated using a validated tool and indicates a low risk of recurrence. The patient states a preference for breast-conserving surgery as part of her treatment plan.
Which one of the following treatment options is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Breast-conserving surgery with no further treatment
Modified radical mastectomy and adjuvant hormonal therapy
Breast-conserving surgery with adjuvant chemotherapy and hormonal therapy
Breast-conserving surgery followed by radiation therapy and adjuvant hormonal therapy
Breast-conserving surgery with complete axillary lymph-node dissection and adjuvant hormonal therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clinical trials have shown that breast-conserving surgery followed by radiation therapy leads to the same overall and disease-free survival rates as mastectomy. The woman in this case desires breast-conserving surgery, this option should be offered in conjunction with radiation therapy. This patient should also receive tamoxifen for 10 years after finishing radiation therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Clinical trials have shown that breast-conserving surgery followed by radiation therapy leads to the same overall and disease-free survival rates as mastectomy. Because the woman in this case desires breast-conserving surgery, this option should be offered in conjunction with radiation therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Adjuvant chemotherapy could be considered if a patient's breast-cancer recurrence score on a validated tool indicated a high risk of recurrence. However, this patient's risk of recurrence is described as being low; in that setting, adjuvant chemotherapy is not recommended because the risks outweigh the benefits.

D) CORRECT:

Clinical trials have shown that breast-conserving surgery followed by radiation therapy leads to the same overall and disease-free survival rates as mastectomy. A meta-analysis conducted by the Early Breast Cancer Trialists’ Collaborative Group investigating data from 7300 women enrolled in breast-conservation trials confirmed that breast irradiation substantially reduced the rate of local recurrence and decreased the 15-year breast-cancer mortality risk (from 31% to 26%) among patients with negative lymph nodes. However, this benefit should be balanced with the increased risk of secondary malignancies and coronary artery disease in patients who receive radiotherapy.

Because the woman in this case desires breast-conserving surgery, this option should be offered in conjunction with radiation therapy. This patient should also receive tamoxifen for 10 years after finishing radiation therapy. If she were postmenopausal, then an aromatase inhibitor would be chosen rather than tamoxifen. Hormonal therapy alone after breast-conserving therapy would not optimally reduce the risk of local recurrence. The hormone receptor status of the patient’s tumor is not a factor in the decision to use radiation therapy with breast-conserving surgery.

Key learning point: To reduce local recurrence and breast-cancer mortality among young women with early-stage breast cancer who are treated with breast-conserving surgery, the treatment plan should generally include irradiation of the breast.

E) INCORRECT:

A complete axillary lymph-node dissection is not needed in this patient because her sentinel lymph nodes are negative for disease. Fewer than 5% of patients have axillary node involvement when sentinel nodes are negative.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 45-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of an itchy rash on her left nipple. The rash began as small vesicles on the nipple and spread to the areola. It has become a painful ulcer with yellow, watery discharge that is occasionally blood-tinged. Her younger sister was diagnosed with endometrial cancer a year ago. Examination shows a weeping, ulcerated lesion involving the entire left nipple-areolar complex. There are no breast masses, dimpling, or axillary lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) would have a rapidly progressive clinical course, and involvement of the nipple-areola complex in IBC can result in itching and ulceration of the nipple as well as bloody nipple discharge. However, more than a third of the breast will be erythematous, tender, indurated, and edematous with a “peau d'orange” appearance. Palpable axillary lymph nodes are present at the time of clinical presentation in > 75% of cases.

B) INCORRECT:

Mastitis may be accompanied by fissuring of the nipple, and periductal mastitis can result in serous, serosanguinous, or purulent discharge. However, mastitis occurs typically among patients who are breastfeeding with an erythematous, tender, and swollen breast, and systemic symptoms such as fever would be present. Blood-tinged nipple discharge is usually not seen.

C) INCORRECT:

A breast abscess typically presents as a tender, palpable, fluctuant lump within the breast with erythema of the overlying skin, and systemic symptoms such as fever.

D) INCORRECT:

A fibroadenoma would present as a solid, nontender, breast lump that slips under the examiner's fingers. Nipple changes and discharge would not be present. Moreover, a fibroadenoma typically occurs in patients between the age of 15–35 years.

E) CORRECT:

Paget disease of the breast is a ductal carcinoma that infiltrates the nipple-areola complex causing an erythematous, scaly, or vesicular rash that is accompanied by pruritus, burning, and/or nipple retraction. The rash eventually ulcerates and causes blood-tinged nipple discharge.
Image Description:

An erythematous, scaling rash with irregular borders and erosion of the nipple is visible on the left breast of a female patient. The pathology extends beyond the areola region.

These findings are typical of Paget's disease of the breast, a rare type of ductal carcinoma that is often accompanied by nipple discharge. Age-appropriate imaging and biopsy are required for diagnosis.
questions.hint: Cytology of this lesion would show intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells within the epidermis of the nipple.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the office because of a lump in her left breast that she first noticed 2 weeks ago. Her medical history is unremarkable. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Her aunt was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at the age of 55 years. The patient has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 9 years and drinks one to two alcoholic beverages weekly. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (139 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg. Palpation of the left breast discloses a firm, rigid, nontender mass in the upper outer quadrant; the overlying skin shows no abnormalities. There is no nipple discharge. Examination of the right breast shows no abnormalities and axillary lymph nodes are not palpable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

BRCA gene testing is recommended for evaluating breast cancer in patients with a family history of breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer, or in some patients after breast cancer (e.g., triple-negative or bilateral breast cancer) is diagnosed. Although this patient has a family history of ovarian cancer, testing is only indicated after the diagnosis is made and if a first-degree relative is affected.

B) CORRECT:

Breast ultrasound is the most appropriate next step when evaluating a palpable breast mass in women < 30 years of age. Premenopausal women < 30 years of age often have dense breast tissue, which decreases the diagnostic accuracy of mammography in these individuals. Furthermore, ultrasound imaging does not expose the patient to ionizing radiation, unlike mammography. Breast ultrasonography helps distinguish solid lesions from benign cysts, as well as evaluate axillary, supraclavicular, and infraclavicular lymph nodes. If imaging reveals signs of malignancy (e.g., mass irregularity, heterogenicity, spiculated margin), mammography, in addition to ultrasound, can be performed and a biopsy of the lesion is indicated.

For women between 30 and 39 years of age, both mammography and ultrasound can be used; mammography is the recommended imaging modality in women ≥ 40 years of age.

Key learning point: Breast ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality for evaluating a palpable breast mass in women under 30 due to higher breast density and avoidance of radiation.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated in the case of a benign breast lesion, such as fibroadenoma, which is the most common breast tumor in women < 35 years of age. Benign breast lesions are typically soft, well-defined, and mobile, unlike this patient's firm, rigid, and nontender mass. This approach is appropriate only after the diagnosis is established.

D) INCORRECT:

Core needle biopsy (CNB) is used to assess a palpable breast mass with findings that suggest malignancy (e.g., firm, rigid, nontender mass). Because CNB has high sensitivity and specificity, it is used to evaluate the extent of the tumor, as well as its histology and receptor profile. Although CNB is part of the workup of breast lumps, it is performed after imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

Mammography is used for the evaluation of palpable breast masses in women ≥ 40 years of age. This screening modality is also recommended for breast cancer screening in this age group (i.e., ≥ 40 years) because it can detect the majority of malignancies and lesions ∼ 2 years before they are clinically evident. However, this imaging modality is less sensitive in younger patients with high breast density.
Image Description:

Mammography (right breast; craniocaudal view)

A mass (circled) with suspicious features, including high density and indistinct margins, is visible in the posterior third of the breast.
questions.hint: A palpable breast mass requires further assessment regardless of the clinical features of the mass and the patient's age.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the office with concerns about swelling and pain in her right breast. A photograph of the patient's chest is shown. Physical examination shows erythema and prominent pitting of the hair follicles overlying the upper and lower outer quadrants of the right breast. There are no nipple changes or discharge. A core needle biopsy shows invasive carcinoma of the breast. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's skin findings?

choices.text: Bacterial invasion of the subcutaneous tissue
Involution of the breast parenchyma and ductal system

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacterial invasion of the subcutaneous tissue of the breast causes mastitis, which can manifest as pain, erythema, and edema of the breast. Although peau d'orange appearance may occasionally be seen, most patients with mastitis will have fever, be actively lactating, or have a recent history of penetrating trauma that incited the infection. This patient has histopathological evidence that the signs are secondary to an invasive carcinoma of the breast.

B) CORRECT:

Obstruction of the dermal lymphatics by malignant tumor cells in inflammatory breast cancer results in localized lymphedema, which manifests as an increase in the size of the breast and the characteristic swollen and pitted appearance of peau d'orange (prominent hair follicle pits). Further signs include itching and nipple retraction. Even with trimodality therapy (i.e., chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and radical mastectomy) the prognosis is poor, as inflammatory breast cancer spreads early.

C) INCORRECT:

Involution of the breast parenchyma and ductal system occurs when the serum estrogen levels begin to decrease during menopause, causing the breasts to decrease in size. This patient is 55 years of age and may be perimenopausal. Although breast involution can result in benign breast cysts manifesting as painful breast lumps, it does not cause erythema, edema, or peau d'orange appearance of the skin, as seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

As the lactiferous ducts converge onto the nipple areolar complex, tumor infiltration of the ducts results in nipple retraction and discharge. While these symptoms may occur in inflammatory breast cancer, they are absent here.

E) INCORRECT:

Tumor infiltration of the breast may be associated with tightening and shortening of the suspensory ligaments (Cooper ligaments). Because these ligaments are attached to the skin, tightening results in localized retraction and dimpling of the skin that changes the normal shape and contour of the breast. It differs from the swelling and pitting of peau d'orange seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This woman has invasive carcinoma of the breast. The diffuse erythema, edema, and pitting of the skin suggest peau d'orange (skin resembling an orange peel), which supports the diagnosis of inflammatory breast cancer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a lump that she noticed in her right breast. She otherwise feels well and has not had any breast pain or nipple discharge. Palpation of the right breast shows a 3-cm firm, nontender mass with well-defined margins lateral to the right nipple. There is a dimpling of the skin overlying the mass but no rash. The left breast is normal. Mammography shows a density with calcifications in a star-shaped formation in the same location as the mass. Microscopic examination of a biopsy specimen from the breast mass shows disorganized nests of glandular cells that express E-cadherin and are surrounded by fibrous tissue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A fibroadenoma, which is the most common benign breast tumor in women, can manifest with a solitary, well-defined, nontender mass and evidence of fibrous and glandular tissue overgrowth on biopsy. However, as a benign condition, fibroadenoma is not associated with dimpling of the skin. Also, while fibroadenoma may show popcorn calcifications, calcifications in a star-shaped formation on mammography are not consistent with this diagnosis. Instead, a fibroadenoma usually appears as a smooth, polylobulated mass on mammography.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of breast tissue (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Compressed glandular spaces, i.e., epithelial component of fibroadenoma (green overlay) and stromal component of fibroadenoma (red overlay), are visible.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) INCORRECT:

Lobular carcinoma-in-situ (CIS) is usually an incidental biopsy finding. A lobular CIS would not cause a breast mass or calcifications on mammography, and tumor cells of lobular CIS typically lose their ability to express E-cadherin.

C) CORRECT:

Disorganized cords and nests of duct-like, glandular cells surrounded by a desmoplastic stroma are characteristic histological findings seen in invasive ductal carcinoma, which is the most common type of invasive breast cancer. Invasive carcinomas can manifest with a palpable breast mass and features of tumor infiltration (e.g., skin dimpling). Unlike in lobular carcinomas, tumor cells of ductal carcinomas often retain E-cadherin expression. The mammography finding of a stellate lesion occurs as a result of clustered microcalcifications of the surrounding tissue.

Key learning point: Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common breast cancer, presenting as a firm mass with skin dimpling, stellate calcifications, and nests of E-cadherin–positive glandular cells in a desmoplastic stroma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of biopsy specimen (H&E stain; low magnification) from a mobile breast lump in 64-year-old female patient

Main image: At low magnification, a dense irregular mass (purple/pink) with poorly circumscribed borders can be seen infiltrating the mature adipose tissue of the breast (white). The mass is composed of disorganized tubular formations of the carcinoma (dark blue/basophilic staining) and surrounding collagenous connective tissue (pink/eosinophilic staining; also known as “desmoplastic stroma”).

Top right inset: very low magnification overview indicating the location of the main image on the specimen

D) INCORRECT:

An invasive lobular carcinoma, which is the second most common type of invasive breast carcinoma, can manifest with a palpable breast mass and calcifications on mammography. However, a biopsy would show orderly rows of monomorphic neoplastic cells in a “single file” pattern without duct formation. In addition, a desmoplastic (fibrous) response is often absent and tumor cells of invasive lobular carcinomas typically lose their ability to express E-cadherin.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a breast tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain; 40x magnification)

Infiltrating malignant cells can be seen as single cells, narrow chords (examples indicated by green overlay), and characteristic single-file formations (examples indicated by blue overlay). The tumor cells are seen growing between distorted ductuli (D) and lobuli (L), surrounded by conspicuously pale connective tissue. There is no tubule formation of the tumor (as is commonly seen in other types of adenocarcinomas of the breast).

This is the typical appearance of invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast.

Click on the microscope icon (at the top) to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive form of invasive breast cancer that classically manifests with an erythematous tender breast, peau d'orange appearance (due to dermal lymphatic invasion), and breast engorgement rather than a palpable breast mass. Peau d'orange appearance is characterized by diffuse breast skin dimpling and is different from the isolated dimpling of skin overlying the breast mass seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Dimpling (puckering) of the skin overlying the breast mass indicates tightening and shortening of the suspensory ligaments (Cooper ligaments) as a result of tumor infiltration.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents for follow-up of an inflamed right breast. Two weeks earlier, she presented with redness, swelling, and tenderness of the entire right breast and has since completed 10 days of oral clindamycin therapy. She notes that her symptoms have not improved. On physical examination, the entire right breast is inflamed. There are no palpable lymph nodes or associated nipple changes. A photograph of the right breast is shown. Which one of the following next steps is most likely to provide a diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Biopsy of the inflamed breast tissue
A therapeutic trial of intravenous vancomycin twice daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although obtaining breast imaging (usually mammography and ultrasound, occasionally MRI) is part of the staging procedure of breast cancer, inflammatory breast cancer is often not detected by these imaging modalities and will therefore not be diagnostic.

B) CORRECT:

Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive type of breast cancer that often manifests with acute swelling, redness, itching, pain, tenderness, and warmth. Nipple retraction and skin changes can occur. It can mimic acute mastitis. A distinct lump can sometimes be felt but not in most cases. Inflammatory breast cancer occurs when cancer cells obstruct lymphatic vessels in breast tissue, leading to edema and inflammation. The only reliable diagnostic tool is biopsy of the inflamed breast tissue.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for a woman with an inflamed breast that has not responded to initial oral antibiotics is biopsy of the inflamed breast tissue.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeating another course of antibiotics, even with intravenous antibiotics like vancomycin, when the first course has failed will not provide a diagnosis, is unlikely to treat a patient who has already received adequate antibiotics, and may further delay diagnosis of a life-threatening disease. It is therefore not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Although obtaining breast imaging (usually mammography and ultrasound, occasionally MRI) is part of the staging procedure of breast cancer, inflammatory breast cancer is often not detected by these imaging modalities and will therefore not be diagnostic.

E) INCORRECT:

Although obtaining breast imaging (usually mammography and ultrasound, occasionally MRI) is part of the staging procedure of breast cancer, inflammatory breast cancer is often not detected by these imaging modalities and will therefore not be diagnostic.
questions.hint: The right breast is swollen and shows diffuse erythema that extends over most of its surface. Conspicuous hair follicles produce the typical orange peel appearance (peau d'orange), which is caused by blockage of lymphatic channels.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulligravid woman presents for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no history of serious illness. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 11 years. She is sexually active with her husband and takes oral contraceptive pills. Her last Pap smear was 3 years ago. She has never had a mammogram. Her mother and maternal aunt died of breast cancer in their early 50s. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: Pap smear now and every 3 years, mammography at age 50 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every year, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear now and every 5 years, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 3 years, mammography at age 40 years
Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 5 years, mammography at age 40 years

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

According to the USPSTF, a Pap smear every 3 years in individuals with a cervix who are 21–29 years of age is an acceptable screening method for cervical cancer. However, an additional test is required as a part of cervical cancer screening starting at the age of 30 years. In addition, breast cancer screening is typically started at 40 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years from 40–74 years of age. Also, this patient should now receive HPV testing along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should not be repeated annually because more frequent testing does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies.

C) INCORRECT:

Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years from 40–74 years of age. Also, the USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening every 5 years starting at 30 years of age. However, when screening every 5 years, the protocol requires another test in addition to the Pap smear. If the additional test cannot be performed, a Pap smear should be taken every 3 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years between 40–74 years of age. Also, the USPSTF recommends an HPV test along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer, starting at 30 years of age. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should be repeated every 5 years rather than every 3 years because more frequent screening does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies.

E) CORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years for individuals with a cervix who are 30–65 years of age and a solitary Pap smear every 3 years for those between 21–29 years of age. This guidance differs from the recently updated ASCCP, ACS, and ACOG guidelines, which recommend that those aged 25–65 years undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing (where available) or HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years. All guidelines recommend a solitary Pap smear every 3 years if HPV testing is unavailable.

Regarding breast cancer, mammography is rarely useful in younger patients, who have naturally denser breast tissue. According to the USPSTF, breast cancer screening with mammography should be performed every 2 years between 40–74 years of age. Screening can be started earlier in patients with first-degree relatives with breast cancer. Breast cancer screening recommendations may differ between medical organizations (e.g., ACOG, ACS). Consult our table “Breast cancer screening for individuals at average risk” for the most up-to-date information on breast cancer screening recommendations.

Whenever the information required to determine the correct answer for an NBME question involves a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF recommendations.
questions.hint: This patient is healthy and requires the standard screening tests for her age group and risk stratification according to USPSTF guidelines.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman visits her physician with a lump in her right breast noticed a few weeks ago. She reports no pain or nipple discharge. She has no known family history of breast cancer. On examination, there is a firm, irregular 2-cm mass in the upper outer quadrant that is fixed. The overlying skin shows a dimpled appearance when she raises her arm. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy.
Which of the following diagnoses best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibroadenomas are benign breast lesions, typically presenting as well-circumscribed, rubbery, and mobile masses in younger women. The described mass is firm, irregular, and fixed, with skin dimpling, indicating adherence to surrounding tissues, which is atypical for fibroadenomas.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrocystic changes manifest as bilateral, diffuse, and sometimes tender nodularity, fluctuating with the menstrual cycle. The patient presents with a solitary, firm, irregular, and fixed mass with skin dimpling, suggesting tissue invasion, which is not characteristic of fibrocystic changes.

C) CORRECT:

Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer, often presenting as a firm, irregular, and fixed mass. The upper outer quadrant is a common location due to the high volume of glandular tissue. Skin dimpling upon arm elevation indicates tumor invasion into surrounding stroma, pulling on Cooper’s ligaments. The absence of pain and nipple discharge aligns with early invasive ductal carcinoma, which often presents subtly. These findings suggest malignant invasion into adjacent tissues, as evidenced by the mass's physical characteristics and associated skin changes.

Key learning point: A hard, non-tender irregular breast lump with skin tethering is characteristic of breast carcinoma, distinguishing it from benign conditions like cysts or fibroadenomas.

D) INCORRECT:

Fat necrosis can present as a firm, irregular mass, often following trauma or surgery. The absence of trauma history and the presence of a fixed mass with skin dimpling, indicating infiltration of adjacent structures, suggest a malignant process rather than fat necrosis.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, comes to your clinic with a 3-week history of right breast pain and itchiness. She reports that her right breast has increased in size over the past 2 weeks. She has not noticed any nipple discharge. Her medical history includes hypertension and vulvar lichen sclerosus. Her current medications are enalapril and topical clobetasol propionate. Her temperature is 37.9°C, pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 127/85 mm Hg. A photograph of her chest is provided. On examination, the right breast is warm and tender to palpation, and there is right-sided nontender axillary lymphadenopathy. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intraductal papilloma is a benign condition that can be seen in women between 40 and 50 years of age. It manifests as a nontender palpable mass close to or behind the nipple or areola, in contrast to the findings in this patient, and it is the most common cause of bloody or serous nipple discharge. Furthermore, this condition does not typically cause breast inflammation.

B) CORRECT:

An acute onset (< 6 months) of edema and erythema that involves at least one-third of the breast with peau d’orange, nipple retraction, and axillary lymphadenopathy raises suspicion for inflammatory breast cancer (IBC). Blood-tinged nipple discharge is also a common finding in patients with IBC. For patients with clinical findings of IBC, a core needle biopsy is indicated to confirm the diagnosis, and if invasive carcinoma is found, two full-thickness skin punch biopsies should be obtained. IBC is a rare but aggressive carcinoma, and most patients have metastatic disease at the time of initial presentation.

Key learning point: Inflammatory breast cancer presents with rapid-onset breast erythema, edema (peau d’orange), tenderness, and axillary lymphadenopathy, and is an aggressive malignancy often diagnosed at an advanced stage.

C) INCORRECT:

Phyllodes tumor of the breast most commonly affects women between 40 and 50 years of age and can have a phase of rapid growth. In contrast to this patient's presentation, however, phyllodes tumor manifests as a painless, smooth, multinodular lump in the breast. Furthermore, this tumor does not typically cause breast inflammation, which this patient has.

D) INCORRECT:

Mastitis manifests with tenderness, warmth, erythema, and edema of the affected breast, as well as reactive lymphadenopathy, all of which are seen in this patient. However, mastitis typically develops in women who are breastfeeding, most commonly within a month postpartum, making this diagnosis unlikely. Furthermore, patients with mastitis present with flu-like symptoms such as fever, chills, and malaise, none of which are seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Paget disease of the breast can manifest with erythema, pruritus, and nipple retraction, all of which are seen here. However, these findings are typically limited to the nipple and areola and do not involve the entire breast.
questions.hint: The photograph shows an edematous, erythematous right breast with noticeable hair follicles, resulting in an orange peel (peau d’orange) appearance, which is highly characteristic of this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of an itchy rash on her left nipple. The rash started as small vesicles on the nipple and spread to the areola, progressing to a painful ulcer with yellow, watery discharge that is sometimes blood-tinged. Her younger sister was diagnosed with endometrial cancer a year ago. On examination, there is a weeping, ulcerated lesion involving the entire left nipple-areolar complex. There are no breast masses, dimpling, or axillary lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A fibroadenoma would present as a solid, nontender, breast lump that slips under the examiner's fingers. Nipple changes and discharge would not be present. Moreover, a fibroadenoma typically occurs in patients between the age of 15–35 years.

B) CORRECT:

Paget disease of the breast is a ductal carcinoma that infiltrates the nipple-areola complex causing an erythematous, scaly, or vesicular rash that is accompanied by pruritus, burning, and/or nipple retraction. The rash eventually ulcerates and causes blood-tinged nipple discharge.

Key learning point: Paget disease of the breast presents as an erythematous, scaly, or ulcerated nipple-areolar rash with pruritus and possible blood-tinged discharge, and is associated with underlying ductal carcinoma.
Image Description:

An erythematous, scaling rash with irregular borders and erosion of the nipple is visible on the left breast of a female patient. The pathology extends beyond the areola region.

These findings are typical of Paget's disease of the breast, a rare type of ductal carcinoma that is often accompanied by nipple discharge. Age-appropriate imaging and biopsy are required for diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) would have a rapidly progressive clinical course, and involvement of the nipple-areola complex in IBC can result in itching and ulceration of the nipple as well as bloody nipple discharge. However, more than a third of the breast will be erythematous, tender, indurated, and edematous with a “peau d'orange” appearance. Palpable axillary lymph nodes are present at the time of clinical presentation in > 75% of cases.

D) INCORRECT:

Mastitis may be accompanied by fissuring of the nipple, and periductal mastitis can result in serous, serosanguinous, or purulent discharge. However, mastitis occurs typically among patients who are breastfeeding with an erythematous, tender, and swollen breast, and systemic symptoms such as fever would be present. Blood-tinged nipple discharge is usually not seen.

E) INCORRECT:

A breast abscess typically presents as a tender, palpable, fluctuant lump within the breast with erythema of the overlying skin, and systemic symptoms such as fever.
questions.hint: Cytology of this lesion would show intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells within the epidermis of the nipple.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to your clinic with concerns about swelling and pain in her right breast. A photograph of her chest is provided. On examination, there is erythema and prominent pitting of the hair follicles over the upper and lower outer quadrants of the right breast. There are no nipple changes or discharge. A core needle biopsy reveals invasive carcinoma of the breast. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for her skin findings?

choices.text: Bacterial invasion of the subcutaneous tissue.
Involution of the breast parenchyma and ductal system.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacterial invasion of the subcutaneous tissue of the breast causes mastitis, which can manifest as pain, erythema, and edema of the breast. Although peau d'orange appearance may occasionally be seen, most patients with mastitis will have fever, be actively lactating, or have a recent history of penetrating trauma that incited the infection. This patient has histopathological evidence that the signs are secondary to an invasive carcinoma of the breast.

B) INCORRECT:

Involution of the breast parenchyma and ductal system occurs when the serum estrogen levels begin to decrease during menopause, causing the breasts to decrease in size. This patient is 55 years of age and may be perimenopausal. Although breast involution can result in benign breast cysts manifesting as painful breast lumps, it does not cause erythema, edema, or peau d'orange appearance of the skin, as seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Obstruction of the dermal lymphatics by malignant tumor cells in inflammatory breast cancer results in localized lymphedema, which manifests as an increase in the size of the breast and the characteristic swollen and pitted appearance of peau d'orange (prominent hair follicle pits). Further signs include itching and nipple retraction. Even with trimodality therapy (i.e., chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and radical mastectomy) the prognosis is poor, as inflammatory breast cancer spreads early.

Key learning point: Peau d’orange skin changes in inflammatory breast cancer result from malignant obstruction of dermal lymphatic channels, leading to localized lymphedema and pitting.

D) INCORRECT:

Tumor infiltration of the breast may be associated with tightening and shortening of the suspensory ligaments (Cooper ligaments). Because these ligaments are attached to the skin, tightening results in localized retraction and dimpling of the skin that changes the normal shape and contour of the breast. It differs from the swelling and pitting of peau d'orange seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

As the lactiferous ducts converge onto the nipple areolar complex, tumor infiltration of the ducts results in nipple retraction and discharge. While these symptoms may occur in inflammatory breast cancer, they are absent here.
questions.hint: This woman has invasive carcinoma of the breast. The diffuse erythema, edema, and pitting of the skin suggest peau d'orange (skin resembling an orange peel), which supports the diagnosis of inflammatory breast cancer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to your clinic after noticing a lump in her right breast. She feels well and has not experienced any breast pain or nipple discharge. On palpation, there is a 3-cm firm, nontender mass with well-defined margins lateral to the right nipple. There is dimpling of the skin overlying the mass, but no rash. The left breast is normal. Mammography reveals a density with calcifications in a star-shaped formation at the site of the mass. Microscopic examination of a biopsy specimen from the mass shows disorganized nests of glandular cells that express E-cadherin and are surrounded by fibrous tissue. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive form of invasive breast cancer that classically manifests with an erythematous tender breast, peau d'orange appearance (due to dermal lymphatic invasion), and breast engorgement rather than a palpable breast mass. Peau d'orange appearance is characterized by diffuse breast skin dimpling and is different from the isolated dimpling of skin overlying the breast mass seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A fibroadenoma, which is the most common benign breast tumor in women, can manifest with a solitary, well-defined, nontender mass and evidence of fibrous and glandular tissue overgrowth on biopsy. However, as a benign condition, fibroadenoma is not associated with dimpling of the skin. Also, while fibroadenoma may show popcorn calcifications, calcifications in a star-shaped formation on mammography are not consistent with this diagnosis. Instead, a fibroadenoma usually appears as a smooth, polylobulated mass on mammography.

C) INCORRECT:

An invasive lobular carcinoma, which is the second most common type of invasive breast carcinoma, can manifest with a palpable breast mass and calcifications on mammography. However, a biopsy would show orderly rows of monomorphic neoplastic cells in a “single file” pattern without duct formation. In addition, a desmoplastic (fibrous) response is often absent and tumor cells of invasive lobular carcinomas typically lose their ability to express E-cadherin.

D) CORRECT:

Disorganized cords and nests of duct-like, glandular cells surrounded by a desmoplastic stroma are characteristic histological findings seen in invasive ductal carcinoma, which is the most common type of invasive breast cancer. Invasive carcinomas can manifest with a palpable breast mass and features of tumor infiltration (e.g., skin dimpling). Unlike in lobular carcinomas, tumor cells of ductal carcinomas often retain E-cadherin expression. The mammography finding of a stellate lesion occurs as a result of clustered microcalcifications of the surrounding tissue.

Key learning point: Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common invasive breast cancer, characterized by E-cadherin–positive glandular cells in a desmoplastic stroma and often presents as a firm mass with stellate calcifications and possible skin dimpling.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of biopsy specimen (H&E stain; low magnification) from a mobile breast lump in 64-year-old female patient

Main image: At low magnification, a dense irregular mass (purple/pink) with poorly circumscribed borders can be seen infiltrating the mature adipose tissue of the breast (white). The mass is composed of disorganized tubular formations of the carcinoma (dark blue/basophilic staining) and surrounding collagenous connective tissue (pink/eosinophilic staining; also known as “desmoplastic stroma”).

Top right inset: very low magnification overview indicating the location of the main image on the specimen

E) INCORRECT:

Lobular carcinoma-in-situ (CIS) is usually an incidental biopsy finding. A lobular CIS would not cause a breast mass or calcifications on mammography, and tumor cells of lobular CIS typically lose their ability to express E-cadherin.
questions.hint: Dimpling (puckering) of the skin overlying the breast mass indicates tightening and shortening of the suspensory ligaments (Cooper ligaments) as a result of tumor infiltration.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to your clinic for follow-up. One month ago, she was diagnosed with carcinoma of the left breast. She underwent a lumpectomy for a 2.1-cm mass and sentinel lymph node biopsy 2 weeks ago. Pathology of the breast mass showed margin-free invasive ductal carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry revealed that the tumour is estrogen-receptor and progesterone-receptor negative, and ERBB2-receptor positive. The lymph node biopsy was negative for metastases. On examination, there is a healing surgical incision over the left breast and no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. You decide to initiate appropriate pharmacotherapy. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Because trastuzumab and anthracyclines are cardiotoxic (e.g., cause dilated cardiomyopathy with systolic congestive heart failure), a detailed evaluation of cardiac function is necessary before initiating therapy. Although chest x-ray may reveal the first signs of cardiomyopathy (e.g., cardiomegaly, lung congestion), it is not the most appropriate next step.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is performed in women who present with abnormal uterine bleeding while on tamoxifen therapy to screen for endometrial cancer. Tamoxifen is the first-line treatment in premenopausal women with estrogen and progesterone-receptor-positive breast cancer, but it may increase the risk of endometrial cancer and uterine sarcoma. However, according to immunohistochemistry, this patient has hormone-receptor-negative cancer cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Fundoscopy is recommended for patients treated with tamoxifen, as it can cause eye dryness, irritation, cataracts, and retinopathy. This patient is hormone-receptor-negative, so tamoxifen is not indicated. Instead, she requires trastuzumab alongside systemic chemotherapy. Although ocular adverse effects, such as corneal epithelial changes, have been reported with trastuzumab, ophthalmology consultation is recommended only when ocular symptoms are present. A different side effect is more common and requires pre-treatment evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

A DEXA scan is indicated for suspected osteoporosis, a complication of long-term therapy with aromatase inhibitors (e.g., anastrozole), which are the first-line treatment in postmenopausal women with hormone-receptor-positive breast cancer. This patient has an ERBB2-positive tumor that responds well to targeted therapy with trastuzumab and chemotherapeutic agents such as anthracyclines, both of which are not associated with a higher risk of osteoporosis.

E) CORRECT:

ERBB2-positive tumors respond well to targeted therapy with trastuzumab and chemotherapeutic agents such as anthracyclines and taxanes. Before initiating treatment, an echocardiogram should be performed to evaluate cardiac function, since trastuzumab, anthracyclines, and taxanes are cardiotoxic (e.g., cause dilated cardiomyopathy with systolic congestive heart failure). The cardiotoxic effects may be limited with dexrazoxane, an iron-chelating agent.

Key learning point: Before starting trastuzumab for HER2-positive breast cancer, baseline echocardiography is essential to assess cardiac function due to the risk of cardiotoxicity.
questions.hint: ERBB2-positive  breast carcinomas require treatment with trastuzumab in addition to systemic chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulligravid woman comes to your clinic with a 10-day history of intermittent, small amounts of blood-tinged discharge from her left nipple. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. She has a 5-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. Her last menstrual period was 12 days ago. She is sexually active and uses condoms inconsistently. On examination, scant serosanguinous fluid is expressible from the left nipple. There is no palpable breast mass or axillary lymphadenopathy. No other abnormalities are found on examination. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum prolactin levels are indicated to screen for hyperprolactinemia if the patient has bilateral milky discharge. This patient presents with unilateral sanguineous nipple discharge, which warrants a different initial step in workup.

B) INCORRECT:

Cytological examination of nipple discharge is not recommended because of its low sensitivity in detecting malignancy, high false-negative rates (a negative cytology does not definitively rule out malignancy), and low-cost effectiveness. In addition, cytology, if positive, does not help localize the lesion nor differentiate between an in situ and invasive carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Mammography is recommended for the evaluation of focal breast findings (e.g., unilateral nipple discharge) in women > 30 years of age. However, this imaging modality is not recommended as the first-line diagnostic test in patients < 30 years of age. Breast tissue is very dense in this group, limiting the efficacy of mammograms to detect small lesions. Furthermore, mammography exposes the patient to ionizing radiation. Another diagnostic test for the evaluation of nipple discharge is, therefore, more appropriate in this patient group.

D) INCORRECT:

Ductography is indicated in patients who present with pathological nipple discharge if other imaging is inconclusive or shows features suspicious of malignancy (e.g., ductal irregularity). Ductography is not routinely indicated for the evaluation of pathological nipple discharge because it is expensive, exposes the patient to radiation, and is technically difficult to perform. Also, most causes of nipple discharge in women < 30 years of age are benign.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with red flags for nipple discharge should be evaluated with imaging studies for lactiferous duct pathologies. Patients > 30 years of age should undergo ultrasonography AND diagnostic mammography or digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) to detect signs of ductal abnormalities (e.g., dilated ducts, ductal mass/nodule). For patients < 30 years of age, subareolar breast ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality. Because breast tissue density is higher in this age group, a mammogram is less effective at detecting small lesions. Also, there is no ionizing radiation exposure associated with ultrasound imaging, unlike during a mammogram. If imaging reveals signs of malignancy, a biopsy of the lesion is indicated. Nonmilky nipple discharge is most commonly caused by benign conditions, such as intraductal papilloma or ductal ectasia, but may also be a sign of underlying malignancy (e.g., ductal carcinoma in situ).

In nonpregnant patients with bilateral, milky (nonbloody) nipple discharge (galactorrhea), laboratory assessment with measurement of serum prolactin levels is the first diagnostic step.

Key learning point: In women under 30 with suspicious nipple discharge, breast ultrasound is the preferred initial diagnostic test.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis
TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone
questions.hint: This patient presents with red flags for nipple discharge (unilateral, spontaneous, and serosanguineous nipple discharge).

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to your clinic with an itchy rash and burning sensation around her left nipple. Her symptoms have progressively worsened over the past 4 months. She has tried ibuprofen and over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream without relief. Her medical history is unremarkable. Her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 65. She has a 20-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. Vital signs are normal. A photograph of the rash is provided. On examination, there is no nipple discharge, palpable breast masses, or axillary lymphadenopathy. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform KOH test on skin scrapings.
Perform punch biopsy of the lesion.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin therapy is indicated for the treatment of skin infections such as erysipelas, which manifests with a sharply demarcated erythematous lesion, similar to what is seen here. However, this patient does not have other common features of erysipelas (e.g., fever and a more acute onset), making this diagnosis less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical calcineurin inhibitors (e.g., tacrolimus) can be used in the management of atopic nipple eczema, which manifests as an itchy, erythematous, scaly lesion around the nipple and areolar region, similar to what is seen here. However, this patient experienced no symptom relief with topical corticosteroid therapy (the mainstay of treatment for atopic eczema), making this diagnosis unlikely. This patient's worsening symptoms despite treatment with topical steroids should raise concern for PDB; a different step is more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Imaging of the breast is indicated in patients with PDB to exclude associated abnormalities (e.g., masses, architectural distortions) and synchronous breast malignancies. However, in patients older than 30 years of age, like this one, bilateral mammography rather than ultrasonography of the breast is indicated. Ultrasonography of the breast is usually indicated as the initial imaging in patients younger than 30 years of age and/or to guide core biopsy of any associated abnormalities.

D) INCORRECT:

KOH testing of skin scrapings is used in the diagnosis of dermatophyte infections, which can manifest with an itchy, erythematous, scaly lesion, similar to what is seen here. However, with time, lesions of dermatophyte infections typically develop into round plaques with central clearing and raised borders, which is not seen here. Moreover, an isolated lesion around the nipple is unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

In patients with clinical findings suggestive of PDB, a punch biopsy of the lesion should be performed, and the visualization of Paget cells on microscopy confirms the diagnosis. Patients with PDB should also undergo bilateral mammography to exclude associated abnormalities (e.g., masses, architectural distortions) and underlying or synchronous breast malignancies (e.g., ductal carcinoma in situ or invasive ductal carcinoma).
