The treatment for PDB can vary depending on these mammographic findings but always includes resection of the lesion and nipple-areolar complex.

Key learning point: Paget disease of the breast presents as a persistent eczematous nipple lesion and requires punch biopsy for diagnosis due to its strong association with underlying breast malignancy.
questions.hint: This patient's itchy, erythematous, scaly rash on the areola should raise concern for Paget disease of the breast (PDB).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She is asymptomatic and has no significant medical history. She is married and has two children. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with a normal flow; her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 38 years, and her maternal aunt died of ovarian cancer at age 45 years. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She takes a daily multivitamin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient underwent genetic testing, which revealed a pathogenic BRCA1 mutation. The patient asks about the most appropriate cancer screening strategy for her situation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Begin annual breast ultrasound and pelvic examination now
Begin annual mammography and annual breast MRI immediately
Begin annual mammography now and annual breast MRI at age 40
Begin mammography every 2 years starting at age 40
Begin annual transvaginal ultrasound and serum CA-125 at age 50

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pelvic examination may be performed annually in patients with high-risk conditions for ovarian cancer, such as BRCA mutations, as part of comprehensive ovarian cancer screening (including annual transvaginal ultrasound and CA-125 levels). However, in patients with a genetic predisposition for breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutation), annual breast ultrasonography is not an appropriate screening strategy as this modality is not sensitive enough for detecting early-stage disease.

B) CORRECT:

Individuals with a genetic predisposition to breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutation) should begin screening from 25–29 years of age. For those aged ≤ 29 years, breast examination every 6–12 months and annual breast MRI are recommended. For those aged ≥ 30 years, annual MRI plus mammography is recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Annual mammography alone is insufficient for high-risk BRCA1 carriers < 40 years of age because younger individuals have relatively dense breast tissue that reduces the test's sensitivity. Delaying annual MRI until 40 years of age risks missing early cancers that may develop in this high-risk group. A different screening approach is more appropriate for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Mammography every 2 years starting at 40 years of age is appropriate for individuals at average risk but not for those at high risk (e.g., BRCA mutation carriers). For high-risk individuals, starting mammography alone at 40 years of age is insufficient because it may miss early cancers and lacks the sensitivity needed to detect tumors.

E) INCORRECT:

Periodic ovarian cancer screening with transvaginal ultrasound and serum CA-125 levels may be considered in individuals at high risk for ovarian cancer (e.g., patients with BRCA mutations) who do not wish to undergo risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy. Ideally, the screening should start earlier, around 30 years of age. Additionally, early breast cancer screening is indicated in this patient.
questions.hint: Early and intensive screening is critical due to the aggressive nature and early onset of BRCA-associated breast cancers.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 6-week history of progressive swelling, redness, and pain in her right breast. She was prescribed a course of cephalexin by an urgent care provider 2 weeks ago, with no improvement. She denies any specific injury or nipple discharge. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the patient's chest is shown.  The right breast is warm and tender to palpation. There is right-sided nontender axillary lymphadenopathy. The skin changes observed on this patient's breast are most directly caused by which of the following pathophysiologic processes?

choices.text: Fibrocystic changes leading to ductal ectasia and stromal edema
Superficial thrombophlebitis of the thoracoepigastric vein
Contraction of Cooper ligaments due to an underlying solid mass

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacterial proliferation within mammary ducts can cause infectious mastitis or a breast abscess, which can present with erythema, pain, and swelling. However, these conditions typically improve with antibiotics. Furthermore, the diffuse peau d'orange skin change is not characteristic of a bacterial infection, which more commonly presents with a focal, fluctuant mass if an abscess has formed.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrocystic changes are a benign condition that can cause breast pain and nodularity, but they do not cause the profound erythema, warmth, and peau d'orange skin changes. This patient's rapidly progressive, unilateral presentation with axillary lymphadenopathy is inconsistent with the typically benign and often cyclical nature of fibrocystic changes.

C) INCORRECT:

Superficial thrombophlebitis of the thoracoepigastric vein, also known as Mondor disease, presents with a painful, palpable, subcutaneous cord on the breast or chest wall. While it can cause localized pain and erythema, it does not cause the diffuse breast edema, warmth, or peau d'orange skin changes described. Axillary lymphadenopathy would also be an uncharacteristic finding.

D) CORRECT:

Peau d'orange (orange peel skin) is caused by the obstruction of dermal lymphatic channels due to tumor growth. This widespread lymphatic obstruction blocks the normal drainage of lymph fluid, leading to lymphedema. The resulting skin edema is tethered by the hair follicles, creating the distinctive pitted or dimpled appearance. The associated erythema and warmth are due to increased blood flow and vascular congestion from the inflammatory response.

E) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of an underlying solid tumor can cause fibrosis and shortening of the suspensory Cooper ligaments, leading to skin retraction or focal dimpling. While this is a sign of breast cancer, it does not explain the diffuse edema, erythema, and characteristic peau d'orange appearance seen in this patient.
questions.hint: The photograph shows an edematous, erythematous right breast with noticeable hair follicles, resulting in an orange peel (peau d’orange) appearance, which is highly characteristic of inflammatory breast cancer.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of a swollen, red, and warm right breast. She completed a course of antibiotics for presumed mastitis with no improvement. Physical examination reveals diffuse erythema and tenderness of the entire breast without a discrete, palpable mass. The axillary lymph nodes are enlarged and firm. Which of the following additional dermatologic findings is most characteristic of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Eczematous, scaly rash involving the nipple
Peau d'orange appearance of the overlying skin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An eczematous, scaly, or ulcerated rash involving the nipple and areola is characteristic of Paget disease of the breast. This condition is caused by the infiltration of the nipple epidermis by malignant cells from an underlying ductal carcinoma. This patient's symptoms involve diffuse erythema and swelling of the entire breast, not a rash localized to the nipple.

B) INCORRECT:

Skin ulceration with purulent drainage can occur with a neglected, advanced breast cancer or a breast abscess. However, the patient's presentation lacks a fluctuant mass suggestive of an abscess, and her symptoms did not improve with antibiotics. While ulceration can be a late finding in inflammatory breast cancer, it is not the most characteristic initial dermatologic sign.

C) CORRECT:

Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is an aggressive malignancy characterized by the invasion of dermal lymphatics by tumor cells. This obstruction of lymphatic drainage leads to lymphedema, causing the skin to become thickened and edematous. The characteristic pitting or dimpling of the skin, known as peau d'orange (French for 'skin of an orange'), results from the swelling around hair follicles, which are tethered to the underlying dermis. Diagnosis of IBC is confirmed with a skin punch biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

Prominent superficial veins can be a non-specific sign of a large, rapidly growing breast mass that causes venous obstruction. However, this finding is not specific to or characteristic of inflammatory breast cancer, which is primarily defined by its inflammatory signs resulting from dermal lymphatic invasion, not venous congestion.
questions.hint: The rapid onset of breast erythema, edema, and warmth in a non-lactating woman that fails to improve with antibiotics, together with enlarged, firm axillary lymph nodes, suggests inflammatory breast cancer.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents with a 5-month history of a persistent, scaly lesion on her left nipple. She reports occasional itching but denies pain or discharge. Topical corticosteroids provided no improvement. Physical examination reveals a unilateral, erythematous, eczematous plaque covering the nipple and areola, with superficial erosion. This presentation is most likely associated with which of the following additional findings?

choices.text: Diffuse cutaneous dimpling of the affected breast
Axillary lymph node tenderness without lymphadenopathy
Similar eczematous changes on the contralateral nipple

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous dimpling, or peau d'orange, is caused by lymphatic obstruction and tethering of suspensory (Cooper's) ligaments by an underlying malignancy. While it is a sign of breast cancer, it is more characteristic of advanced tumors or inflammatory breast cancer. It is not the most common finding associated specifically with Paget disease.

B) INCORRECT:

In breast cancer, axillary involvement manifests as firm, non-tender, and enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy). Axillary tenderness without palpable lymphadenopathy is a non-specific finding, more commonly associated with inflammatory or infectious conditions (reactive lymphadenitis) rather than metastatic spread from a breast carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Benign inflammatory conditions like atopic or contact dermatitis can present with bilateral nipple changes. However, Paget disease of the breast is characteristically a unilateral condition, as it stems from a primary malignancy within a single breast ductal system. Bilateral presentation is exceptionally rare.

D) INCORRECT:

Purulent nipple discharge suggests an infectious etiology, such as mastitis or a breast abscess, which typically presents with pain, warmth, and systemic signs of infection. While Paget disease may occasionally be associated with serous or bloody discharge, a purulent exudate is not a characteristic feature. The patient also denies any discharge.

E) CORRECT:

Paget disease of the breast is a rare form of breast cancer presenting as a persistent, eczematous, and ulcerative lesion of the nipple-areolar complex. This condition arises from malignant cells, known as Paget cells, migrating from an underlying ductal carcinoma (either in situ or invasive) to the epidermis of the nipple. Therefore, the most common associated finding is a palpable subareolar mass, which is present in approximately 50-60% of cases. The presence of a palpable mass is a significant prognostic factor, as it typically indicates an underlying invasive carcinoma and is associated with a higher incidence of axillary lymph node metastases.
questions.hint: The unilateral, eczematous nipple changes that are refractory to topical corticosteroids should raise a strong suspicion for Paget disease of the breast.

questions.text: A 52-year-old asymptomatic woman undergoes her routine annual screening mammogram. She has no personal history of breast disease and her family history is noncontributory. She is postmenopausal and does not use hormone replacement therapy. On physical examination, her breasts are symmetric and non-tender without palpable masses, skin changes, or nipple discharge. Axillary examination is unremarkable. The radiologist identifies an area of concern, and a subsequent stereotactic biopsy confirms ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Which of the following mammographic findings most likely prompted the biopsy?

choices.text: A spiculated mass with architectural distortion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A spiculated mass with architectural distortion is a highly suspicious mammographic finding. However, it is the classic sign of invasive ductal carcinoma, not DCIS. The spiculations represent a desmoplastic reaction, which is a host fibrotic response to tumor cells invading the surrounding breast stroma. The diagnosis in the stem is explicitly DCIS, a non-invasive process that typically does not create a stromal reaction or a palpable mass.

B) INCORRECT:

These features describe secretory calcifications, also known as plasma cell mastitis, which are a classic benign finding. They are coarse, rod-like calcifications that form within ectatic (dilated) ducts and tend to point toward the nipple. Their large size and lucent centers are reassuring features, not suspicious for malignancy, and are not the typical appearance of DCIS-associated calcifications.

C) INCORRECT:

Milk-of-calcium calcifications are a benign finding representing calcium sediment layering within microcysts. They are typically diffuse, scattered, and often bilateral. On different mammographic views, they classically change appearance, looking amorphous on one view and forming crescent-shaped 'teacups' on another. This pattern is not suspicious for malignancy and is unrelated to the pathophysiology of DCIS.

D) CORRECT:

Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a non-invasive breast cancer where malignant cells are confined to the breast ducts. The most common mammographic presentation is microcalcifications, which are found in over 80% of cases. As the neoplastic cells rapidly proliferate and pack the duct, they can outgrow their blood supply, leading to central necrosis and subsequent dystrophic calcification. These calcifications are typically pleomorphic (varying in size and shape) and appear in a clustered, linear, or segmental distribution, reflecting the anatomy of the involved ductal system. This patient's asymptomatic presentation and non-palpable disease detected on screening mammography are classic for DCIS.

E) INCORRECT:

A smooth, well-circumscribed, oval mass on mammography is typically a benign finding. These features suggest a non-infiltrative process, with common etiologies including a fibroadenoma or a simple cyst. While some malignancies can present this way, it is not the characteristic finding that leads to a diagnosis of DCIS, which was confirmed by biopsy in this patient.
questions.hint: In this non-invasive malignancy, malignant cells proliferate within a duct, and central necrosis often develops, producing a characteristic imaging finding.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a persistent rash on her left nipple for the past 5 months. She reports intermittent itching and a burning sensation, with occasional blood-tinged discharge. A course of high-potency topical corticosteroids prescribed by a previous provider offered no improvement. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the rash is shown. Gentle palpation reveals a firm, non-tender, 2-cm mass in the retroareolar region. The contralateral breast and axillary lymph nodes are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for Paget disease of the breast, a rare form of breast cancer. It is characterized by the infiltration of the nipple and areolar epidermis by malignant cells (Paget cells) originating from an underlying ductal carcinoma. Clinically, this manifests as a unilateral, erythematous, scaling plaque with symptoms like pruritus, burning, and discharge. The failure of the rash to improve with topical corticosteroids is a key feature distinguishing it from benign dermatoses. The presence of a palpable retroareolar mass is found in over 50% of cases and strongly suggests an associated invasive ductal carcinoma, which carries a poorer prognosis than Paget disease without a mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Nipple eczema can present with an erythematous, scaling, and pruritic rash on the nipple and areola. However, eczema is often bilateral and, crucially, should show at least some improvement with a course of high-potency topical corticosteroids. The lack of response to steroid therapy and the presence of an underlying firm mass make eczema highly unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory breast cancer is a consideration for any erythematous breast changes. However, it typically presents with diffuse erythema, edema, and warmth involving a large portion of the breast, often with a peau d'orange appearance due to dermal lymphatic invasion. This patient's lesion is a well-demarcated plaque, which is not the typical presentation for inflammatory breast cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Mammary duct ectasia involves the dilation of the major lactiferous ducts and can present with nipple discharge (often thick and multicolored) and a palpable retroareolar mass due to inflammation and fibrosis. However, it does not cause the chronic, scaling, eczematoid plaque on the skin surface of the nipple and areola seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Intraductal papilloma is a benign tumor within a milk duct and is the most common cause of unilateral, spontaneous, serosanguinous nipple discharge. While it can sometimes be associated with a small, non-palpable or palpable subareolar mass, it does not cause persistent surface skin changes.
questions.hint: The combination of a unilateral eczematoid lesion that is refractory to topical steroid treatment should raise high suspicion for an underlying malignancy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is evaluated following a new diagnosis of breast cancer. A core needle biopsy of a 2.5 cm mass in her right breast revealed invasive ductal carcinoma. The pathology report confirms the tumor is estrogen receptor-negative, progesterone receptor-negative, and HER2-positive. The oncology team plans to initiate neoadjuvant therapy, including a taxane-based chemotherapy and trastuzumab. Prior to administering the first cycle of this regimen, which of the following evaluations is most critical to obtain?

choices.text: PET/CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis
BRCA1 and BRCA2 germline mutation analysis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A bone scan is used to detect osseous metastases, which are common in breast cancer. This is a component of the staging workup, often performed for patients with clinical stage IIB or higher disease or those with symptoms concerning for bone metastases. It is part of the overall disease assessment but is not a prerequisite safety evaluation before starting trastuzumab.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is scheduled to receive trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody that targets the HER2 receptor. A major and well-known adverse effect of trastuzumab is cardiotoxicity, which can manifest as an asymptomatic decline in left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) or, less commonly, symptomatic congestive heart failure. The risk is increased when used concurrently with anthracyclines. Therefore, a baseline cardiac function assessment with an echocardiogram to measure LVEF is mandatory before initiating therapy. Cardiac function must also be monitored regularly throughout the course of treatment. A significantly reduced baseline LVEF may be a relative or absolute contraindication to trastuzumab therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Cancer antigen 27.29 is a serum tumor marker for breast cancer. While a baseline level may be obtained, its primary role is in monitoring for recurrence or assessing treatment response in the metastatic setting, not for initial diagnosis or staging. It is not sensitive or specific enough for initial workup and is not a required safety check before starting therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

A PET/CT scan is a valuable tool for staging breast cancer, particularly for locally advanced disease (tumors >5 cm or node-positive) or suspected metastatic disease. While it provides crucial information for the overall treatment plan, it is not the most critical evaluation required to ensure patient safety before administering the first dose of a trastuzumab-containing regimen.

E) INCORRECT:

Germline genetic testing for mutations like BRCA1 and BRCA2 is important for assessing hereditary cancer risk and can influence long-term management, such as surgical choices or eligibility for poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase inhibitors. However, this information is not required to assess the immediate safety of initiating the planned neoadjuvant chemotherapy and trastuzumab regimen.
questions.hint: The planned treatment regimen includes a monoclonal antibody targeting the HER2 receptor, which is associated with a characteristic adverse effect.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents for follow-up after an abnormal screening mammogram. She has a history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril. A diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound revealed a 1.5 cm spiculated mass in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast. A core needle biopsy was performed, and pathology confirms invasive ductal carcinoma. The tumor is estrogen receptor-positive, progesterone receptor-positive, and HER2/neu-negative. On examination, a firm, non-tender, 1.5 cm mass is palpated in the left breast. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in this patient's management?

choices.text: Referral for genetic counseling and BRCA testing
Begin external beam radiation to the left breast
Staging with a whole-body PET/CT scan

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Genetic counseling and testing are important considerations in breast cancer management, as a positive result can influence surgical decisions and family screening. However, based on current guidelines, a 62-year-old woman with ER-positive breast cancer and no other mentioned risk factors (e.g., a strong family history) does not meet the highest-priority criteria for immediate testing. While it may be considered later, the most critical next step is to address the known cancer with surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s tumor is hormone–receptor–positive, making endocrine therapy with an aromatase inhibitor, such as anastrozole, an essential part of treatment. However, this is typically given as adjuvant therapy after definitive surgical resection to reduce recurrence risk.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy is a critical component of treatment for reducing local recurrence, but it is used as an adjuvant therapy after surgery. It is almost always given after a lumpectomy to treat the remaining breast tissue.

D) CORRECT:

The primary treatment for early-stage, resectable invasive breast cancer is surgical removal of the tumor. A surgical consultation is necessary to discuss the options, which include breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) followed by radiation, or mastectomy. The surgeon will also perform a sentinel lymph node biopsy to pathologically stage the axilla. All subsequent adjuvant treatments, such as radiation, endocrine therapy, or chemotherapy, are planned based on the definitive surgical pathology. Given the small tumor size and clinically negative nodes, this patient has early-stage disease for which surgery is the critical first step toward a cure.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic staging is used to detect distant metastases. However, for patients with clinical Stage I or II breast cancer and no signs or symptoms of metastatic disease, the risk of finding distant metastases is very low. Guidelines do not recommend routine systemic imaging with PET/CT, CT, or bone scans in this setting, as it is low-yield and can lead to false positives. Systemic staging is reserved for patients with more advanced disease (e.g., locally advanced or inflammatory breast cancer) or concerning symptoms.
questions.hint: For a newly diagnosed, localized solid tumor like invasive breast cancer, the cornerstone of curative-intent treatment is local control.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician 1 week after noticing a lump in her right breast. Fifteen years ago, she was diagnosed with osteosarcoma of her left distal femur. Her father died of an adrenocortical carcinoma at the age of 41 years. Examination shows a 2-cm, firm, immobile mass in the lower outer quadrant of the right breast. A core needle biopsy of the mass shows adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis in this patient is most likely to show a defect in which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

RET proto-oncogene mutations are associated with MEN 2A and MEN 2B syndromes, and medullary thyroid carcinoma. This patient has no history of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma or primary hyperparathyroidism, making MEN 2A and MEN 2B unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

KRAS proto-oncogene encodes a GTPase that regulates cellular growth. KRAS proto-oncogene mutations are associated with colon cancer, non-small cell lung cancers, and pancreatic cancers, but not with breast, adrenal or bone malignancies.

C) CORRECT:

Genetic analysis in this patient is most likely to show a TP53 tumor suppressor gene mutation resulting in Li-Fraumeni syndrome. TP53 regulates cell apoptosis and cell cycle arrest at the G1 phase (by activating p21) and inhibits entry in the S phase of the cell cycle. In the absence of the normal activated p53 protein, cells containing damaged DNA can proliferate, resulting in malignant transformation. Common malignancies include osteosarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, and adrenocortical carcinomas.

See “Overview of tumor suppressor genes” table.

D) INCORRECT:

BRCA mutations are associated with an increased risk of breast cancer and ovarian cancer, as well as colon, pancreas, stomach and prostate cancer. They are not associated with osteosarcoma and adrenocortical carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

MLH1 is a DNA mismatch repair gene. Mutation in this gene is associated with Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and breast cancer. Osteosarcoma and adrenocortical carcinoma are more commonly associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome.

F) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the PTEN gene are associated with prostate cancer and Cowden syndrome. Osteosarcoma and adrenal tumors are not usually associated.

G) INCORRECT:

Rb gene encodes retinoblastoma protein, which deactivates E2F transcription factors, thereby preventing G1 phase to S phase transition. Mutations in Rb gene are associated with retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma but not with breast or adrenal cancers.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a personal history of malignancy (osteosarcoma, adenocarcinoma) at an early age and a family history of early-onset malignancy (adrenocortical carcinoma). The age of onset and type of malignancies are highly suggestive of the autosomal dominant disorder Li-Fraumeni syndrome.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents with a newly detected 2-cm mass in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast, discovered incidentally on self-examination, to the Outpatient Clinic. She reports no personal or family history of breast cancer. On physical examination, the mass is firm, non-tender, and slightly mobile, with no axillary lymphadenopathy. Her serum electrolytes and complete blood count are normal (see reports).

Mammogram: Suspicious spiculated lesion measuring 2.0 cm with microcalcifications
Ultrasound: Irregular hypoechoic mass with associated acoustic shadowing

Which of the following is the best next step in confirming the diagnosis and guiding further management?

choices.text: Open surgical excisional biopsy of the mass
Fine-needle aspiration cytology of the mass
MRI of the breast for lesion characterization
Core needle biopsy of the mass

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Open surgical excisional biopsy is more invasive than needle-based techniques and is generally reserved for cases where core biopsy is not feasible or yields non-diagnostic results. The suspicious imaging features make the lesion accessible for less invasive core needle biopsy, which provides sufficient tissue for histopathological evaluation and facilitates optimal surgical planning.

B) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is minimally invasive but only collects cytological material, lacking tissue architecture necessary for distinguishing between in situ and invasive processes. The imaging features suggest malignancy, and FNAC may yield nondiagnostic results, delaying definitive diagnosis and treatment planning.

C) INCORRECT:

Breast MRI is used for screening high-risk populations or preoperative assessment, not for definitive diagnosis when conventional imaging is highly suspicious. The lesion's malignant features on mammography and ultrasound necessitate histopathological confirmation rather than additional imaging, as MRI does not provide tissue diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

The imaging findings of a suspicious spiculated lesion with microcalcifications on mammography and an irregular hypoechoic mass with acoustic shadowing on ultrasound suggest a high likelihood of malignancy. Core needle biopsy provides a tissue sample that preserves architectural features, allowing for definitive histopathological evaluation, including tumor grade and molecular markers. This method is less invasive than surgical excisional biopsy and offers more diagnostic information than fine-needle aspiration, making it the optimal step for confirming the diagnosis and guiding treatment planning.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected breast cancer with a palpable mass and suspicious mammogram findings, a needle core biopsy is the preferred diagnostic step as it provides sufficient tissue for histological examination and receptor status assessment.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath on exertion for 5 months. She reports that she can not climb more than 2 flights of stairs and she is no longer able to run her errands as usual. One year ago, she was diagnosed with triple-negative breast cancer. She underwent a right-sided modified radical mastectomy and adjuvant chemotherapy. Cardiac examination shows a laterally displaced point of maximal impulse. Coarse inspiratory crackles are heard in both lower lung fields. Echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30%. The physician informs the patient that her symptoms are most likely due to an adverse effect of her chemotherapy. The drug most likely responsible for the patient's current symptoms belongs to which of the following groups of agents?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of breast cancer. This drug is associated with cardiotoxicity, which can manifest as decreased left ventricular ejection fraction and features of heart failure, as seen here. However, trastuzumab is only indicated in cases of ERBB2-positive breast cancer. Since this patient was diagnosed with triple-negative breast cancer, it is unlikely that she was treated with this drug.

B) INCORRECT:

Alkylating agents (e.g., busulfan, cyclophosphamide, chlorambucil) are not typically used in the treatment of breast cancer. Adverse effects are various, but alkylating agents are unlikely to cause cardiotoxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Vinca alkaloids (vincristine, vinblastine) are not typically used in the treatment of breast cancer and are unlikely to cause cardiotoxicity. The most common adverse effects associated with vinca alkaloids are neurotoxicity (especially vincristine) and myelosuppression (especially vinblastine).

D) INCORRECT:

Antimetabolites (e.g., azathioprine, methotrexate, 5-fluorouracil) are not typically used in the treatment of breast cancer and are unlikely to cause cardiotoxicity. The most common adverse effect associated with antimetabolites is myelotoxicity.

E) INCORRECT:

Topoisomerase I inhibitors (irinotecan, topotecan) are not typically used in the treatment of breast cancer and are unlikely to cause cardiotoxicity. The most common adverse effect associated with topoisomerase I inhibitors is myelosuppression.

F) CORRECT:

Anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin) are associated with an increased risk of developing dilated cardiomyopathy with left heart failure, which is seen in this patient. Adjuvant chemotherapy with anthracyclines is usually recommended in patients with triple-negative breast cancers because these tumors are more aggressive than other types of breast cancer and do not respond to other treatment options (e.g., hormone and targeted biologic therapy with tamoxifen and trastuzumab). Concomitant treatment with the iron-chelating agent dexrazoxane can prevent anthracycline cardiotoxicity.
Image Description:

A visual mnemonic illustrating what organ damage is associated with which chemotherapeutic agent.
questions.hint: This patient's signs and symptoms (dyspnea, laterally displaced point of maximal impulse, bilateral inspiratory crackles) and her echocardiographic findings (limited left ventricular ejection fraction) indicate left heart failure. This heart failure was most likely caused by a drug with cardiotoxic side effects that is used to treat breast cancer.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 43-year-old woman comes to the physician 2 weeks after she felt a lump in her right breast. The lesion is not painful and has not increased in size since she first noticed it. Her menses occur at regular 28-day intervals; her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Medical history is unremarkable. Her maternal grandmother underwent a modified radical mastectomy for breast cancer at the age of 73 years. She drinks 3 to 4 glasses of wine on weekends and does not smoke cigarettes. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 126/74 mm Hg. Examination of the breasts show no skin or nipple changes. A firm, nontender 0.5-cm mass is palpated in the outer upper quadrant of the right breast. There is no lymphadenopathy and the remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Mammography shows heterogeneously dense breast tissue; no focal lesion is found. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance and repeat mammography in 1 year

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a clinically palpable breast mass and an indeterminate mammogram, an MRI is indicated only if another imaging modality is also inconclusive. For routine screening, an annual MRI is only performed for women with a high risk of breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutation carriers or those with genetic syndromes that predispose them to breast cancer, patients with previous chest irradiation, family history of early-onset breast or ovarian cancer), a history of breast augmentation (e.g., breast implantation), and/or previous breast cancer. At this time, the patient does not have any indications for breast cancer screening with MRI.

B) INCORRECT:

In patients ≥ 40 years of age with a palpable breast mass, reassurance and repeat mammography in accordance with the routine screening guidelines (annually according to ACOG and every 2 years according to USPSTF) would be appropriate if the initial mammogram conclusively shows findings of a benign mass. In patients with a palpable breast mass and indeterminate results on mammography, repeating a mammogram in 1 year without characterizing the mass would not be appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Because breast density decreases during menses, diagnostic or screening mammography may be delayed until the first week of menses for increased accuracy. In addition, some benign breast lesions (e.g., fibroadenoma) change in size during menses and may be better visualized by mammography during this time. However, if the mammography has been performed for a patient with a clinically palpable breast mass and is inconclusive, a different step should be performed regardless of the timing of the initial mammogram in relation to the menstrual cycle.

D) INCORRECT:

An excisional biopsy of the breast mass (i.e., lumpectomy) is performed to remove a suspected breast malignancy (and a safety margin of healthy tissue, in some cases). An excisional biopsy is only performed if a fine needle aspiration or core needle biopsy is not feasible or if its results are inconclusive. Moreover, a breast tissue biopsy should only be performed after the mass is properly localized and characterized in imaging studies.

E) CORRECT:

Mammography is the first-line imaging modality in patients ≥ 30 years with a palpable breast mass. Ultrasonography is indicated for all patients with indeterminate results on mammography; findings that indicate malignancy include hypoechoic or spiculated masses with ill-defined borders and posterior acoustic shadowing. Patients with such ultrasound findings should undergo a fine needle aspiration or core needle biopsy.

In patients < 30 years of age with a palpable breast mass and findings on clinical assessment that indicate a high probability of malignancy (e.g., positive family history of breast cancer, skin changes, lymphadenopathy, fixation of the mass to the skin or chest wall, nipple retraction, breast asymmetry), ultrasonography is the first-line imaging modality because the relatively high density of breast tissue in this age group often makes mammography inconclusive. A patient < 30 years of age with a palpable breast mass and a low probability of malignancy on clinical assessment should be observed for 1–2 months. If the mass persists, a repeat breast ultrasound should be performed; no further management is necessary if the mass resolves.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis
questions.hint: In patients with a palpable breast mass and inconclusive mammography, further workup is required to screen for breast cancer.
